Increase in renal perfusion due to agonist action on D1 receptors
Releases noradrenaline and causes positive inotropic effect
Direct action on heart via beta-1 receptors

questions.text: Among the following properties of dopamine, which of them is not helpful in acute shock?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Increase in renal perfusion due to agonist action on D1 receptors

 

Explanation:

 

Dopamine is an inotropic agent, with action on D1-receptors as well as beta-1-adrenergic receptors.

 

At low infusion rate (2–10 mcg/kg per minute):

  • The action is mainly on D1-receptors.
  • It causes vasodilation.
  • Low dose infusion of dopamine causes an increase in GER and renal blood flow.

 

At intermediate infusion rates (2–10 mcg/kg per minute):

  • Dopamine stimulates both D1 and beta-1 receptors.
  • Dopamine exerts a positive inotropic effect on myocardium via its action on beta-1 adrenergic receptors. This increases systolic BP.

 

At high infusion rates (10–20 mcg/kg per minute):

  • Dopamine stimulates D1, beta-1 and alpha-1 receptors.
  • It also augments norepinephrine release from nerve terminals.
  • These actions are useful in treatment of shock with oligourea (Dopamine is DOC).
  • Cardiostimulant (beta 1) and vasopressor (alpha 1) action along with release of NA from nerve terminals is useful for increasing blood pressure in acute shock. Renal vasodilator action does not increase BP but help in reversing oligourea.

questions.text: A hospital administrator is trying to optimize the utilization of health services. He aims to strike a balance such that the hospital beds are neither over-utilized nor underutilized. This can be gauged through the bed turnover interval which measures the amount of time beds in a hospital are unoccupied until the next patient's admission following a patient's discharge. To achieve optimum utilization of health services in the hospital, the bed turnover interval should ideally be:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Slightly positive


Explanation:

 

The Bed turnover interval gives an indication of the bed occupancy status in a hospital. Slight positive values in bed turnover interval indicate optimum utilization of services. This means that there is just enough time between the discharge of one patient and the admission of the next, ensuring efficient use without under or overburdening the hospital resources.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Largely positive: This implies a longer period of bed vacancy, which indicates underutilization of services possibly due to an inefficient admission process or poor-quality medical care.

 

Option C. Slightly negative: This suggests that the hospital is at or above 100% occupancy, hinting at a scarcity of beds and potentially over-utilizing services.

 

Option D. Largely negative: This would mean a significant over-utilization of beds, with potential overburdening of resources and even patient care quality being compromised.

 

Educational Objective

 

Bed turn over interval: Amount of time beds at hospital are unoccupied until next patients’ admission following a patients’ discharge. Bed turn-over ratio is a type of heath care utilization rate. Slight positive values indicates optimum utilization of services.

questions.text: Priya, a 28-year-old office worker, presented with irritation and redness of her left eye at a local clinic. She had no previous history of eye problems or immunizations. On examination, a greyish-white membrane was noted over the bulbar and palpebral conjunctiva, which bled upon peeling. What is the likely etiology?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Corynebacterium diphtheria

 

Explanation:

 

Let's explain each option:

 

Option A. Corynebacterium diphtheria: Corynebacterium diphtheria can cause a characteristic greyish-white membrane over the conjunctiva, known as diphtheritic conjunctivitis. However, this infection is rare in developed countries due to widespread vaccination against diphtheria.

 

 

Option B. Moraxella lacunata: Moraxella lacunata is not a common cause of conjunctivitis characterized by a greyish-white membrane. It is more associated with bacterial conjunctivitis presenting with purulent discharge.

 

Option C. Moraxella axenfeld: Moraxella axenfeld is not a recognized pathogen in conjunctivitis. It is a rare species of bacteria, and its role in ocular infections is limited.

 

Option D. Chlamydia trachomatis: Chlamydia trachomatis is a common cause of trachoma, which can present with a greyish-white membrane over the conjunctiva, known as trachomatous inflammation follicular (TF). It often occurs in areas with poor sanitation and is a common cause of blindness worldwide.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Corynebacterium diphtheria can cause a characteristic greyish-white membrane over the conjunctiva.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old male presents to your clinic with a skin lesion on his arm. He reports that the area around the lesion has reduced sensation to touch. On examination, you also note a thickened ulnar nerve. A skin biopsy is taken which shows acid-fast bacilli. Considering the initiation of multidrug therapy (MDT) for leprosy, which of the following criteria should be satisfied to start MDT?

 

  1. Hypopigmented patch with sensory loss
  2. Peripheral nerve thickening
  3. Peripheral nerve thickening with sensory loss
  4. Skin biopsy demonstrating bacilli
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 3

 

Explanation

 

To start multidrug therapy (MDT), the criteria that should be satisfied are a hypopigmented patch with sensory loss and/or peripheral nerve thickening with sensory loss

 

  • Paucibacillary leprosy has sensory loss (hypo-anesthesia) but may or may not have nerve involvement
  • Multibacillary leprosy has sensory loss (hypo-anesthesia) and nerve involvement

 

Educational Objective

 

Operational Classification of Leprosy (according to skin smear positivity) to serve as a basis for Chemotherapy

 

 

(BI: Bacteriological Index; OAMS: Once a month supervised)

 

* MBL cases are most important source of infection

 

* MDT is safe in pregnancy

questions.text: A forensic expert is conducting an autopsy and observes a clot with a distinctive layered appearance, resembling chicken fat, within the blood vessels of the deceased. This finding is characteristic and indicative of a specific type of thrombus. What type of thrombus is associated with a 'chicken fat' appearance?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Postmortem thrombus

 

Explanation

 

The 'chicken fat' appearance is typical of a postmortem thrombus, which is also known as a postmortem clot. These clots can form after the cessation of blood circulation and are often found during autopsies. They have a gelatinous and layered structure, which can be easily distinguished from antemortem thrombi that are firmer and attached to the vessel walls. Antemortem thrombi are formed due to pathophysiological processes while the person is still alive and typically indicate a thrombotic event such as a heart attack or stroke.

 

Two types of Postmortem thrombus:

 

Red currant jelly: Occurs if the blood clots rapidly. RBCs do not have time to settle down hence RBCs are distributed in whole clot and hence the clot is uniformly dark red

 

Chicken fat: Occurs if the clotting is gradual. RBCs settle down and two different layers are seen:

 

Upper layer: A pale layer of serum and fibrin

 

Lower layer: Red (like red current layer)

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Antemortem thrombus is firmly adheres to the lining endothelium, with a pale, granular and transversely ridged surface because of alternating layers of platelets and fibrin.

 

Option C. Gunshot injury - Gunshot wounds are typically characterized by tissue damage, bullet paths, stippling, and soot deposition depending on the range and calibre of the weapon used. Does not lead to thrombus. 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Appearances of thrombus:

choices.text: Elevated serum glucose
Antibody to double stranded DNA
Elevated antistreptolysin O titer
Antiglomerular basement membrane antibody

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl was brought to the family physician because of increasing lethargy for 5 days. She had a sore throat 15 days prior to the office visit. On physical examination, she has periorbital edema. Initial laboratory studies show a serum BUN of 25 mg/dL and creatinine 2.7 mg/dL. A microscopic urinalysis shows hematuria with dysmorphic RBC's. The light microscopic appearance of her renal biopsy shows hypercellularity with PMN's present. The electron microscopic appearance is shown. Which of the following additional laboratory test findings is most likely to be present in this girl?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Elevated antistreptolysin O titer

 

Explanation for each option:

 

Option A. Elevated serum glucose:

 

  • Elevated serum glucose levels are indicative of diabetes or hyperglycemia. However, there is no direct association between elevated serum glucose and the clinical presentation described, which includes periorbital edema, elevated BUN and creatinine, hematuria with dysmorphic RBCs, and a renal biopsy showing hypercellularity.

 

Option B. Antibody to double-stranded DNA (anti-dsDNA):

 

  • Anti-dsDNA antibodies are associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). While SLE can present with renal involvement (lupus nephritis), it typically does not manifest with periorbital edema and elevated BUN and creatinine. Additionally, the electron microscopic appearance of the renal biopsy image is not consistent with lupus nephritis.

 

Option C. Elevated antistreptolysin O titer (ASO titer):

 

  • Elevated ASO titers are indicative of recent streptococcal infection, such as streptococcal pharyngitis (strep throat). The patient's history of sore throat and the presence of periorbital edema suggest a post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN). This condition can lead to renal involvement, elevated BUN and creatinine, and hematuria with dysmorphic RBCs.

 

Option D. Antiglomerular basement membrane antibody (anti-GBM antibody):

 

  • Anti-GBM antibodies are associated with anti-GBM antibody disease or Goodpasture syndrome. This condition primarily affects the lungs and kidneys, leading to glomerulonephritis and pulmonary hemorrhage. While it can present with renal involvement, it typically does not cause periorbital edema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) is an immune-mediated glomerular disease that occurs following a streptococcal infection, such as streptococcal pharyngitis (strep throat) or impetigo. PSGN can lead to renal involvement, characterized by periorbital edema, elevated BUN and creatinine, hematuria with dysmorphic RBCs, and immune complex deposition in the glomeruli. Elevated antistreptolysin O (ASO) titers are a diagnostic marker for recent streptococcal infection in PSGN.

questions.text: In a 30-year-old male, nerve conduction study (NCS) was done to evaluate the pathophysiology of both sensory and motor nerve injuries. Which of the following types of A nerve fibers are expected to have the highest conduction velocity?

  • A fibers have conduction velocity of 15-30 m/s and Aδ fibers have conduction velocity of 12-30 m/s.

Laboratory studies show a β-human chorionic gonadotropin level of 103,000 mIU/L. The sample shown in the image is retrieved from the patient’s uterus. There are no recognizable fetal parts. questions.text: This figure represents the mechanism of drugs used in the treatment of parkinsonism. Which of the following options correctly represents the drugs shown in the figure?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) a: Pramipexole, b: Entacapone, c: Selegiline, d: Carbi-dopa

 

The mainstay of treatment for Parkinson's disease is the use of dopaminergic medications, which increase the levels of dopamine in the brain.

 

These medications can be:

 

  1. Dopamine precursors: These medications are converted into dopamine in the brain and include levodopa (L-dopa) and its combination with carbidopa. Carbidopa prevents the breakdown of levodopa in the bloodstream (by inhibiting dopa decarboxylase enzyme), allowing more of it to reach the brain.
  2. Dopamine agonists: These medications mimic the action of dopamine in the brain and include pramipexole and ropinirole.
  3. MAO-B inhibitors: These medications block the breakdown of dopamine in the brain and include selegiline and rasagiline.
  4. Catechol-O-methyl transferase (COMT) inhibitors: These inhibit the metabolism of levodopa and dopamine. These are used in 0 combination with levodopa to prolong its effect. Examples of COMT inhibitors include entacapone and tolcapone.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the interactions between human immune cells and pathogens. They are particularly interested in the complement receptor that binds C3d, an opsonization product. Which of the following receptors is primarily involved in this binding and is being investigated for its role in enhancing B cell responses?
questions.solution:
Ans. B)  CR2

 

Explanation:

 

CR2, also known as CD21, is the receptor that binds to C3d, a complement fragment that opsonizes pathogens, facilitating their recognition and removal. CR2/CD21 is primarily found on B cells and follicular dendritic cells and is involved in enhancing the immune response, particularly the B cell response.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CR1 - CR1 (CD35) binds to C3b and C4b fragments and is involved in the clearance of immune complexes.

 

Option C. CR3 - CR3 (CD11b/CD18) is involved in phagocytosis but does not bind C3d.

 

Option D. CR4 - CR4 (CD11c/CD18) is similar to CR3 and is also not primarily responsible for binding C3d.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Receptors used by viruses:

questions.text: In evaluating the causes behind early neonatal morbidity and mortality rates (ENNMR) in a tertiary care hospital, a Pediatrician seeks to identify the predominant factors contributing to these outcomes. Understanding the most common cause of ENNMR is crucial for developing effective prevention and management strategies in neonatal care. Given the complex interplay of various neonatal and maternal factors, which of the following is recognized as the primary cause of ENNMR?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Prematurity and congenital anomalies

 

Explanation:

 

Prematurity and congenital anomalies are the leading causes of early neonatal morbidity and mortality.

 

Neonatal mortality rate (NNMR): Is the number of neonatal deaths (deaths within completed 28 days after birth) per 1000 live births in that year

 

  • Early neonatal mortality (ENNM): Neonatal mortality in first week (1-7 days) of life
  • Late neonatal mortality (LNNM): Neonatal mortality in first to fourth week (8 – 28 days) of life
  • NNMR is directly related with birth weight and gestational age
  • NNMR boys >NNMR girls

 

Causes of Neonatal mortality (0 – 4 weeks):

 

  • Low birth weight and prematurity (MCC)
  • Birth injury and difficult labour (Option C)
  • Sepsis (Option D)
  • Congenital anomalies
  • Hemolytic diseases of newborn
  • Conditions of placenta and cord
  • Diarrhoeal diseases (Option B)
  • Acute respiratory infections
  • Tetanus

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • MCC of NNMR in India is Preterm birth
  • MCC of ENNMR: Prematurity and congenital anomalies
  • MCC of LNNMR: Infections (diarrhea and tetanus)

choices.text: Development of the ureteric buds
Closure of the rostral neural tube
Formation of the tracheoesophageal septum
Migration of neural crest cells to the distal

questions.text: A baby boy dies several hours after birth. He was born with wrinkled skin, deformed limbs, and abnormal facies. The mother’s pregnancy was complicated by oligohydramnios. Which of the following embryologic processes most likely failed in this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Development of the ureteric buds

 

Explanation for each option:

 

Option A. Development of the ureteric buds: This is the correct answer. The ureteric buds are embryologic structures that give rise to the ureters, renal pelvis, calyces, and collecting ducts. Failure in the development of the ureteric buds can lead to renal agenesis (absence of one or both kidneys), which can cause oligohydramnios due to the lack of urine production by the fetus. The absence of amniotic fluid results in the compression of the fetus, leading to the physical anomalies described (Potter sequence).

 

Option B. Closure of the rostral neural tube: This process is important for the development of the brain and the skull. Failure in this process leads to neural tube defects such as anencephaly or encephaloceles, but would not directly result in the constellation of findings described in the scenario, particularly the oligohydramnios.

 

Option C. Formation of the tracheoesophageal septum: This process is crucial for the separation of the trachea and esophagus during embryonic development. Abnormalities in this process can lead to tracheoesophageal fistula or esophageal atresia. While these conditions are serious, they do not typically result in oligohydramnios or the described physical anomalies.

 

Option D. Migration of neural crest cells to the distal colon: This process is essential for the development of the enteric nervous system, particularly the ganglion cells in the colon. Failure of this migration leads to Hirschsprung's disease, characterized by a lack of ganglion cells in the distal colon, resulting in functional obstruction. Hirschsprung's disease would not cause oligohydramnios or the described physical anomalies.

 

Educational Objective: Understand the embryological basis of congenital anomalies and their clinical manifestations. Specifically, recognize the association between renal development (ureteric bud formation) and its impact on amniotic fluid volume, as well as how oligohydramnios can lead to Potter sequence, characterized by limb deformities, facial anomalies, and pulmonary hypoplasia due to fetal compression.

questions.text: A 69-year-old, slightly obese female presented with complaints of nausea, epigastric pain, vomiting, and tenderness, which she described as radiating or boring through her back for the past 48 hours. Her total cholesterol was elevated (greater than 200) on her last trip to the physician’s office. On physical examination, she is slightly tachycardic, BP is 100/60, and her temperature is 102. You noted that she was slightly jaundiced and has slight abdominal distension. She had diminished bowel sounds, and on palpation, tender but has no rebound pain and did not guard her abdomen. It was suspected that the patient was suffering from pancreatitis secondary to gallstones. Serum and urinary amylase, serum lipase, glucose, calcium levels, WBC, bilirubin – all of which were elevated except for the calcium, which was lowered. In addition, the patient’s CT demonstrated that some pancreatic tissue did not enhance with IV contrast, indicative of necrotizing pancreatitis. The patient was referred to a surgeon and taken to the O.R. for surgical debridement and placed on antibiotics. Blood supply to the pancreas is by all the following except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Left colic artery

 

Left colic is a branch of inferior mesenteric artery that supplies the splenic flexure, descending colon, left 1/3rd of the transverse colon.

 

Incorrect answers:

 

Option A. Gastroduodenal artery arises from common hepatic artery, it gives rise to posterior superior and anterior superior pancreaticoduodenal arteries that supplies the head of pancreas.

 

Option B. Pancreatic branches and dorsal pancreatic branches from splenic artery supply the body and tail of pancreas.

 

Option C. The superior mesenteric artery also supplies the head via the anterior and posterior inferior pancreaticoduodenal arteries.

 

Ref: Vishram Singh Textbook of Anatomy, 3rd edition, vol. II, Abdomen, page no. 131

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a 50 pack year history of smoking cigarettes has recently experienced an episode of hemoptysis along with his usual cough. On physical examination, he has no abnormal findings. A sputum for cytology on microscopic examination shows atypical cells with hyperchromatic nuclei and orange-pink cytoplasm. Laboratory studies show a serum calcium of 11.3 mg/dL, with phosphorus 2.1 mg/dL. Which of the following chest radiographic findings is this man most likely to have?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Large hilar mass

 

This is the most likely finding associated with the patient's symptoms and laboratory results. A large hilar mass can cause hemoptysis and a cough. Hypercalcemia is suggestive of a paraneoplastic syndrome often seen in squamous cell carcinoma of the lung, which can present as a central hilar mass. The description of atypical cells with hyperchromatic nuclei and orange-pink cytoplasm is suggestive of malignancy, consistent with a diagnosis of lung cancer.

 

Explanation for each option:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of hemoptysis, a significant smoking history, hypercalcemia, and cytological findings of atypical cells are highly suggestive of a large hilar mass, likely due to a lung malignancy such as squamous cell carcinoma, which can produce paraneoplastic hypercalcemia.

Stimulation of progesterone receptor activity
Suppression of LH secretion
Enhancement of FSH release

questions.text: In the management of endometriosis, which of the following is the primary mechanism of action of danazol?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inhibition of estrogen production

 

Explanation

 

  • Danazol is an isoxazole derivative of 17-alpha ethinyl testosterone.
  • It is strictly anti-gonadotropin but acts as an androgen agonist.
  • Mode of action: The mechanism of action is complex and includes the following:
    • Acting on the hypothalamo-pituitary gonadal axis → depression of frequency of GnRH pulses → suppression of pituitary FSH and LH surge. There is, however, no change in the basal gonadotropin level while the estrogen levels are reduced.
    • Reduces the liver synthesis of SHBG and as such, free testosterone is increased which in turn causes endometrial atrophy.
    • Acts directly on the ovaries, inhibiting the enzymes responsible for steroidogenesis – reducing the estrogen level
    • Binds with steroid receptors on the endometrium and also in the ectopic endometrial sites
    • Immunologic effects of danazol include decrease in serum immunoglobulins, interleukin-1 and TNF production. This effect helps in the regression of endometriosis.
  • The net result is production of an hypoestrogenic state
  • Indications of use of Danazol: (Although it is now not very commonly used)
    1. Endometriosis
    2. Precocious puberty
    3. AUB
    4. PMS
    5. Symptomatic fibroid
    6. Benign fibrocystic disease of the breasts (mastalgia)
    7. Prior to hysteroscopic endometrial ablation, to make the endometrium thin
  • Side effects of Danazol:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Indications of use of Danazol: (Although it is now not very commonly used)
    1. Endometriosis
    2. Precocious puberty
    3. AUB
    4. PMS
    5. Symptomatic fibroid
    6. Benign fibrocystic disease of the breasts (mastalgia)
    7. Prior to hysteroscopic endometrial ablation, to make the endometrium thin

 

Ref: DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition, Page no. 530

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman develops gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN), 8 months after abortion. Her hCG value is 1,20,000 mIU/mL. Chest X-ray shows metastasis. The appropriate treatment for her would be:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) EMA-CO regimen

 

The patient has stage 3 disease (lung mets).

 

Her score would be: previous pregnancy: abortion: 1, 8 months: 2, hCG >1 lac: 4, lung mets:0, number of mets: not provided, size of tumor: not given in question.

 

Based on this information, her score is 7, which Is a high risk GTN.

questions.text: Identify the material attached to the burn wound in the picture below.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Biobrane

 

Option A. Biobrane. Biobrane is a biosynthetic wound dressing made of a silicone membrane and a nylon fabric partially embedded with collagen. It adheres to the wound bed of superficial burns, creating a protective barrier that facilitates the body's healing process. Because of its semi-permeable nature, it allows for the exchange of fluids and gases, which helps to maintain a moist healing environment without the need for frequent dressing changes.

 

Option B. Amniotic Graft. Amniotic grafts are derived from the amniotic membrane part of the placenta. They are used in burn care and wound management for their natural therapeutic properties, which include anti-inflammatory factors and growth-promoting effects. These grafts can reduce scar formation, pain, and healing time.

 

 

Option C. Hydrocolloid Dressings (Duoderm). Hydrocolloid dressings like Duoderm are made of gel-forming agents like pectin or gelatin. They provide a moist and insulated healing environment, which can help in the management of light to moderately exuding wounds. These dressings are self-adhesive and can conform to the wound site, but they need to be changed every few days.

 

 

Option D. Vaseline Impregnated Gauze. This type of dressing consists of gauze that has been saturated with petrolatum (Vaseline). It is non-adherent, which makes it a good choice for wounds with fragile skin where the dressing needs to be changed without causing trauma. It helps keep the wound moist and protected from outside contaminants.

 

 

Educational objective - Biobrane is a biosynthetic wound dressing made of a silicone membrane and a nylon fabric partially embedded with collagen used for burns dressings.

choices.text: Inhibition of oxidative phosphorylation

questions.text: As increased intracellular calcium is detrimental to the cell, calcium homeostasis is tightly regulated both across the cell membrane and within the cell via sequestration in the endoplasmic reticulum and mitochondria. In which of the following ways does increased intracellular calcium concentration cause the most cell damage?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Enzyme activation

 

Explanation for each option:

 

Option A: Enzyme activation - Increased intracellular calcium can lead to the activation of various enzymes within the cell. For example, calcium can activate proteases, which are enzymes that break down proteins, and lipases, which break down lipids. This can result in the degradation of cellular proteins and membranes, leading to cell damage and, in severe cases, cell death.

 

Option B: Free radical generation - While calcium itself doesn't directly generate free radicals, it can trigger processes that lead to the production of reactive oxygen species (ROS), which are free radicals. Excessive ROS can damage cellular components, including DNA, proteins, and lipids, contributing to cell injury and various diseases.

 

Option C: Increased membrane permeability - Elevated intracellular calcium levels can disrupt the integrity of cell membranes, including the plasma membrane and organelle membranes. This increased permeability can lead to the leakage of ions and other molecules, disrupting cellular functions and potentially causing cell death.

 

Option D: Inhibition of oxidative phosphorylation - High intracellular calcium levels can interfere with mitochondrial function, including oxidative phosphorylation, which is critical for energy production in cells. Inhibition of this process can lead to decreased ATP production, affecting various cellular processes and potentially causing cell damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The question addresses the detrimental effects of increased intracellular calcium concentration on cells. Calcium homeostasis is crucial for normal cell function, and disruptions in calcium regulation can lead to cell damage and various pathological conditions. Understanding the mechanisms by which elevated calcium levels can harm cells helps in grasping the importance of maintaining calcium homeostasis within cells to preserve their integrity and function.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with a history of chronic alcohol abuse presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset chest pain and dyspnea. He reports that the symptoms occurred after an episode of intense retching following a night of heavy drinking. A chest CT scan is performed and reveals the findings shown in the image. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pneumomediastinum

 

Explanation for each option:

 

Option C. Pneumomediastinum: This is the correct diagnosis. Pneumomediastinum is the presence of air in the mediastinum, the central compartment in the thoracic cavity that contains the heart, major blood vessels, trachea, esophagus, and thymus. In this case, the sudden onset of chest pain and dyspnea following intense retching, combined with the physical examination findings of subcutaneous emphysema (air in the subcutaneous tissues of the neck and upper chest) and discomfort when swallowing, are classic signs. The chest CT showing air in the mediastinum without evidence of pneumothorax or pleural effusion further supports this diagnosis. Pneumomediastinum can occur due to alveolar rupture from increased intra-alveolar pressure (as might happen with violent retching), allowing air to dissect along the bronchovascular sheaths into the mediastinum.

 

Option A. Pneumothorax: This is the presence of air in the pleural space, which can cause the lung to collapse. While the symptoms of chest pain and dyspnea could be consistent with pneumothorax, the absence of pneumothorax on the CT scan rules out this diagnosis. Pneumothorax would typically show a visible rim of air outside the lung contour.

 

Option B. Pneumoperitoneum: This is the presence of air within the peritoneal cavity, often due to gastrointestinal perforation. While abdominal pain and signs of peritonitis would be more common in pneumoperitoneum, the patient's symptoms are primarily respiratory and related to the thoracic cavity, and the CT scan findings do not indicate air in the abdominal cavity, making this diagnosis unlikely.

 

Option D. Consolidation: This refers to the filling of the lung alveoli with fluid, pus, blood, cells, or other substances, leading to a region of lung tissue that appears solid on imaging. Common causes include pneumonia and pulmonary edema. The patient's symptoms and CT findings do not suggest consolidation, as there is no evidence of solid areas within the lung parenchyma on the scan.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The key educational objective here is to understand the clinical presentation and diagnostic approach to pneumomediastinum, particularly in the context of sudden-onset chest pain and dyspnea following an episode of intense retching. It is important to recognize the significance of subcutaneous emphysema and the specific CT findings that differentiate pneumomediastinum from other causes of acute chest pain, such as pneumothorax, pneumoperitoneum, and consolidation.

choices.text: Supplementation with Pancreatic Lipase
Inhibition of Gastric Lipase
Administration of a Bile Salt-Binding Resin
Supplementation with Brush Border Enzymes

questions.text: A 56-year-old male with a history of chronic pancreatitis presents with steatorrhea. Based on the fat absorption pathway, which of the following therapeutic interventions is most appropriate to improve his fat malabsorption?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Supplementation with Pancreatic Lipase

 

Option A: Correct. Pancreatic lipase supplementation helps digest fats in patients with pancreatic insufficiency

 

 

The image illustrates the role of pancreatic lipase in the digestion of fats and the formation of micelles.

 

In chronic pancreatitis, pancreatic enzyme deficiency, including lipase leads to fat malabsorption and steatorrhea.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Gastric lipase plays a minor role in fat digestion; inhibiting it would not be beneficial.

 

Option C: Bile salt-binding resins would exacerbate fat malabsorption by reducing bile salt availability.

 

Option D: Brush border enzymes do not compensate for the role of pancreatic lipase in fat digestion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pancreatic lipase supplementation is a key treatment for patients with fat malabsorption due to chronic pancreatitis.

 

Ref: Ganong’s Review of Medical physiology, 25th edition, page no. 474, 754.

questions.text: A pediatrician is consulted for a 6-month-old infant presenting with acute gastroenteritis characterized by severe diarrhea and vomiting. The mother mentions that the child had recently started attending a local daycare. Stool analysis reveals the presence of a rotavirus. Which of the following enterotoxins is most likely responsible for the child's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A)  NSP4

 

Explanation:

 

In cases of rotavirus infection, NSP4 (Non-structural Protein 4) is known to act as an enterotoxin. It disrupts calcium homeostasis and leads to diarrhea. This scenario, featuring an infant with acute gastroenteritis and a confirmed rotavirus infection, points to NSP4 as the responsible enterotoxin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. NSP6 - NSP6 is not recognized as an enterotoxin in rotavirus infections.

 

Option C. VP3 - VP3 is not an enterotoxin associated with rotavirus.

 

Option D. VP7 - While VP7 is a structural protein of the rotavirus, it is not responsible for the enterotoxin activity leading to diarrhea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The specific enterotoxin (NSP4) involved in rotavirus gastroenteritis, is a common cause of diarrhea in infants and young children.

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-c, 2-b, 3-d, 4-a

 

Explanation:

 

  1. Headache localized to occiput/vertex is often associated with sphenoid sinusitis. The sphenoid sinuses are located deep within the skull, behind the eyes. When they become inflamed, the pain can be referred to the back of the head, which is the occiput or the top of the head, known as the vertex. Thus, 1 matches with c (Sphenoid sinusitis).
  2. Pain over the bridge of the nose aggravated by movements of the eyeball is typically a symptom of ethmoid sinusitis. The ethmoid sinuses are located between the eyes and inflammation here can cause pain that is felt around the eyes and can be exacerbated by eye movements. Hence, 2 matches with b (Ethmoid sinusitis).
  3. Pain over the upper jaw aggravated by chewing is characteristic of maxillary sinusitis. The maxillary sinuses are located in the cheekbones, right beneath the eyes, and inflammation or infection can cause pain that is felt in the upper jaw, particularly when chewing. Therefore, 3 matches with d (Maxillary sinusitis).
  4. An office headache that starts in the morning and reduces by evening is often due to frontal sinusitis. The frontal sinuses are located above the eyes, in the forehead region. Pain and pressure from inflammation of the frontal sinuses can lead to a headache that is more pronounced in the morning and improves as the day progresses. Thus, 4 matches with a (Frontal sinusitis).

 

Educational Objective:

 

To identify the characteristic pain patterns associated with inflammation of different sinus areas, which can aid in the clinical diagnosis of sinusitis.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents to the emergency department after falling from his bicycle. On examination, he has a fractured right ulna and is in severe pain, requiring intravenous analgesia. The medical team decides to insert a pink-coloured IV cannula for medication administration and fluid resuscitation. The nurse informs you that the only available cannula on the pediatric ward is 20-gauge. What is the approximate flow rate you can expect with a pink 20-gauge IV cannula?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 61 mL/min

 

Explanation: IV cannulas are color-coded to indicate their size, which correlates with the maximum flow rate they can deliver. A 20-gauge pink IV cannula typically has a flow rate of about 61 mL/min. This is a medium-sized cannula that allows for moderate fluid flow and is commonly used for adults and children when large volumes of fluid are not needed rapidly.

 

Educational objective:

choices.text: Cyclothymic disorder
Persistent depressive disorder (dysthymia)
Premenstrual dysphoric disorder

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman comes to the office due to weight gain and low self-confidence. She says, "I've always had trouble with my weight and mood swings. I've gained 11 pounds [5 kg] in the last 2 years and feel horrible about myself. I go through this cycle in which I feel good, stick to a diet, and exercise for a couple of weeks, but then my mood gets really down. I start eating junk food and feel bloated until I get my period.” The patient is also upset about a recent fight with her best friend, saying "I blame myself because I am much more irritable before my period, and I lashed out at her for no reason. The following week I felt much better, but the damage was done." The patient has struggled with moodiness and being overweight for most of her adult life. She says, "I hate when I feel this way because, generally, I'm a pretty upbeat person.” Physical examination and laboratory evaluation are unremarkable. BMI is 29kg/m². Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Premenstrual dysphoric disorder

 

Explanation for each option:

 

Option B: This patient's cyclical pattern of overeating, mood swings, and irritability, which worsen prior to menstruation and resolve for a few weeks at a time, is suggestive of premenstrual dysphoric disorder (PMDD).PMDD, a severe variant of premenstrual syndrome (PMS), is characterized by prominent mood symptoms, including sadness, mood swings, anger, anxiety, irritability, and decreased interest, as well as fatigue, changes in appetite, and physical discomfort (eg, bloating, breast tenderness). These mood symptoms decrease in intensity or resolve completely after menstruation.

 

Option A: Bulimia nervosa is characterized by episodes of excessive, uncontrollable eating within a specified period (e.g., 1-2 hr) that occur at least once a week for 3 months. In bulimia nervosa, this is accompanied by compensatory behaviors such as fasting, laxative abuse, or excessive exercising. Compared with patients with these eating disorders, this patient describes more cyclical pattern of overeating, together with mood lability and irritability, finding consistent with PMDD.

 

Option B: Although irritability can be a symptom of hypomania, as seen in cyclothymic disorder, this patient does not have a history of other hypomanic symptoms (e.g., increased energy, decreased need for sleep, pressured speech, grandiosity), which is required to diagnose these disorders.

 

Option C: Mood changes in the premenstrual phase are common, requiring differentiation of PMS and PMDD from premenstrual worsening of another medical or psychiatric condition. For example, patients with persistent depressive disorder (dysthymia), a chronic form of depression, may describe premenstrual exacerbation of depressive symptoms. However, careful history-taking in such a patient shows that depressive symptoms are present at other times during the menstrual cycle, unlike in this patient, who has 2 weeks of feeling good before the mood changes occur. The accurate diagnosis of PMDD requires prospective daily ratings for ≥2 cycles demonstrating a symptom-free period in the follicular phase.

 

Educational objective:

 

Premenstrual dysphoric disorder is characterized by cyclical mood swings, irritability, appetite changes, and physical discomfort that resolve after menses. It is not diagnosed when premenstrual mood symptoms represent an exacerbation of an underlying disorder in which the symptoms are not limited to the premenstrual phase.

choices.text: Factor VIII
Alpha fetoprotein

questions.text: A 49-year-old man complains of pain in his left thigh for 3 months. On physical examination, his thigh is increased in size, compared to the right. A plain film radiograph reveals the presence of a 15 cm solid mass that does not appear to arise from bone, but it does have infiltrative margins. A biopsy of this mass is taken, and on microscopic examination, the mass is composed of highly pleomorphic spindle cells. Which of the following immunohistochemical markers is most likely to be demonstrated in the cells of this mass?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vimentin

 

Explanation for each option:

 

Option D. Vimentin:

 

  • Vimentin is an intermediate filament protein and is often used as an immunohistochemical marker to identify mesenchymal cells, including spindle cells. Spindle cell tumors, such as sarcomas, often express vimentin.

 

Option A. Factor VIII:

 

  • Factor VIII is not an immunohistochemical marker used to identify spindle cell tumors. It is a coagulation factor.

 

Option B. Cytokeratin:

 

  • Cytokeratin is an intermediate filament protein commonly used as an immunohistochemical marker to identify epithelial cells. It is not typically expressed in spindle cell tumors.

 

Option C. Alpha fetoprotein:

 

  • Alpha fetoprotein is a tumor marker used in the diagnosis of certain types of tumors, particularly hepatocellular carcinoma and germ cell tumors. It is not associated with spindle cell tumors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Spindle cell tumors are composed of elongated, spindle-shaped cells, and they can arise from various tissues. Immunohistochemical markers like vimentin are commonly used to help identify the mesenchymal origin of these tumors and differentiate them from other types of tumors.

questions.text: A 35-year-old Female presented with dysphagia, regurgitation and weight loss. On barium swallow, following appearance was seen. What is the gold standard test to diagnose this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Esophageal manometry

 

  • The above condition is that of achalasia cardia.
  • The barium swallow shows a typical “bird-beak” appearance.
  • The gold standard for the diagnosis of achalasia is esophageal manometry.
  • Manometric features of achalasia cardia are as follows:
    • Incomplete lower esophageal sphincter relaxation
    • Ineffective peristalsis of the esophageal body
    • Elevated LES pressure
  • Achalasia cardia is caused due to the degeneration of the neurons in the myenteric plexus of the esophagus. This degeneration results in the failure of relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) on swallowing.
  • The patients present with a classic triad of dysphagia, regurgitation, and weight loss.
  • The dysphagia initially begins with liquid foods and then progresses to solid foods.
  • As the food gets accumulated in the esophagus, patients may complain of halitosis.
  • With further progression of the disease, the patients may develop pneumonia, lung abscess, etc.
  • The initial diagnosis is made by endoscopy or barium swallow, which shows the presence of dilated esophagus due to the constriction of the lower esophageal sphincter (bird-beak appearance).
  • It is a premalignant condition and can cause squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus.

 

Educational objective: The barium swallow shows a typical “bird-beak” appearance in achalasia cardia which is diagnosed by esophageal manometry.

choices.text: Closure of AV valves
Atrial systole
Closure of semilunar valves
Rapid ejection

questions.text: The following heart sound marked (purple arrow) in the picture will be heard because of:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Closure of semilunar valves  

 

  • The heart sound marked here is the second heart sound.
  • The second heart sound (called S2) will be heard because of the closure of the aortic valve (left side) and pulmonary valve (right side).
  • This sound will be a rapid snap as these semilunar valves will close rapidly (compared to the atrioventricular valves).
  • The first heart sound (called S1) will be heard because of the closure of the atrio-ventricular (AV) valves (mitral valve on the left side and tricuspid valve on the right side).

 

 Refer: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 2nd South Asia edition, page no. 213

choices.text: Staphylococcus aureus

questions.text: The following Gram stain shows most likely which organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. C)   Streptococcus pneumoniae 

 

Explanation: 

 

Gram positive cocci in pair, lanceolate shaped with a halo (i.e. capsule) is suggestive of Streptococcus pneumoniae.

 

Other options: 

 

Option A. Neisseria meningitidis - 

 

Figure: Meningococci in CSF smear (gram-negative diplococci, lens shaped) 

 

Option B. Staphylococcus aureus- 

 

 

Figure: A. Direct smear showing gram positive cocci in clusters with pus cells B. Culture smear showing gram positive cocci in clusters 

 

Option D. Streptococcus pyogenes

 

 

Figure: A. Streptococcus in gram smear of pus B. Streptococcus in culture smear showing gram positive cocci in chains

 

Educational objective -

choices.text: Markedly elevated D-dimer
Tear drop cells in peripheral blood
Decreased leukocyte alkaline phosphatase

questions.text: A 63-year-old man has had back pain for 6 months. He recently developed a cough productive of yellowish sputum. On physical examination, he has no lymphadenopathy or splenomegaly. His temperature is 37.8°C. A radiograph of the spine reveals several 1 to 2 cm lytic lesions of the vertebral bodies. His serum urea nitrogen is 28 mg/dL and creatinine 3.0 mg/dL. A sputum culture grows Streptococcus pneumoniae. A bone marrow biopsy is performed, and the marrow smear is shown here. Which of the following laboratory test findings is most likely to be present in this man?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hypergammaglobulinemia


Explanation for each option:

 

Option D. Hypergammaglobulinemia - This condition is characterized by increased levels of immunoglobulins and is often associated with plasma cell dyscrasias, like multiple myeloma, which this patient's presentation suggests. The back pain, lytic bone lesions, renal insufficiency (as evidenced by the elevated creatinine), and a bone marrow biopsy showing atypical plasma cells strongly point towards multiple myeloma.

 

Option A. Markedly elevated D-dimer - D-dimer is a fibrin degradation product present in the blood after a blood clot is degraded by fibrinolysis. It is typically elevated in conditions such as deep vein thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, or disseminated intravascular coagulation. This patient's presentation is not suggestive of these conditions.

 

Option B. Tear drop cells in peripheral blood - Tear drop cells, or dacryocytes, are often associated with myelofibrosis and other myeloproliferative disorders. While bone marrow abnormalities are present, the symptoms and radiographic findings of lytic lesions are more suggestive of a plasma cell disorder.

 

Option C. Decreased leukocyte alkaline phosphatase - This finding is typically associated with chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML), which does not fit the clinical picture or the marrow findings described in the stem. CML usually presents with an elevated white blood cell count and often with splenomegaly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The patient's symptoms of chronic back pain, radiographic evidence of lytic bone lesions, renal insufficiency, and a marrow smear suggestive of plasma cell proliferation are most consistent with hypergammaglobulinemia, likely secondary to multiple myeloma.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with a 3-month history of unilateral nasal obstruction, intermittent epistaxis, and a noticeable mass in the neck. On examination, a neck mass is palpable on the left side, and nasopharyngoscopy reveals a mass in the nasopharynx. Biopsy confirms the diagnosis of nasopharyngeal carcinoma. Given the location of the primary tumor, which anatomical site in the nasopharynx is the most common origin of nasopharyngeal carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fossa of Rosenmüller

 

Explanation: Nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC) most commonly arises from the fossa of Rosenmüller, which is a lateral recess in the nasopharynx located posterior to the medial end of the Eustachian tube opening. This area is thought to be particularly susceptible to NPC due to its lymphoid tissue content, which can undergo malignant transformation, possibly influenced by Epstein-Barr virus infection, dietary factors, and genetics.

 

Option A. The Eustachian tube orifice is an important anatomical landmark in the nasopharynx but is not the most common site for the origin of NPC.

 

Option C. The nasopharyngeal roof, or the superior wall of the nasopharynx, is less commonly involved in NPC compared to the fossa of Rosenmüller.

 

Option D. The posterior nasopharyngeal wall is another potential site for NPC but is less frequently involved compared to the fossa of Rosenmüller.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To identify the fossa of Rosenmüller as the most common site for the origin of nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman has been complaining of chronic constipation for several months. She has been taking a laxative regularly for relief. She underwent colonoscopy which reveals the presence of dark black discoloration of colon (melanosis coli). Which of the following medications is most likely causing this discoloration of the colon?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Senna

 

Explanation for each option:

 

Option B. Senna.

 

  • Senna is a stimulant laxative known to cause melanosis coli.
  • Senna is a stimulant laxative used to treat constipation.
  • Prolonged and excessive use of senna can lead to melanosis coli, a benign condition characterized by dark discoloration of the colon.

 

Option A. Liquid paraffin.

 

  • Liquid paraffin is a lubricant laxative that is not typically associated with melanosis coli.
  • Liquid paraffin is a mineral oil laxative used to relieve constipation.
  • It lubricates the stool and intestinal walls to ease passage.

 

Option C. Bisacodyl.

 

  • Bisacodyl is another stimulant laxative known to cause melanosis coli.
  • Bisacodyl is used for short-term relief of constipation.
  • Similar to senna, prolonged use can result in melanosis coli.

 

Option D. Psyllium.

 

  • Psyllium is a bulk-forming laxative and is not associated with melanosis coli.
  • Psyllium is a plant-based fibre supplement used to promote regular bowel movements by adding bulk to the stool.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Melanosis coli is a benign and reversible condition of the colon characterized by dark discoloration. It is often associated with the chronic and prolonged use of certain laxatives, particularly stimulant laxatives like senna and bisacodyl. Healthcare providers should be aware of this condition when evaluating patients with chronic constipation who have a history of laxative use.

choices.text: A spike-and-dome pattern of deposition on electron microscopy
A tram-track pattern on light microscopy
Lumpy subepithelial deposits on electron microscopy
Nonlinear mesangial staining with IgA immunofluorescence

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with a history of large-bowel obstruction is diagnosed with colon cancer and undergoes resection of his colon. At check-up, he feels well except that over the past three weeks, he has had significant swelling in his legs. Physical examination reveals 2+ pitting edema and a blood pressure of 155/94 mmHg. Urinalysis shows 4+ protein with no RBCs or casts. Which of the following would most likely be present on a kidney biopsy from this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A spike-and-dome pattern of deposition on electron microscopy

 

Explanation for each option:

 

Option A. A spike-and-dome pattern of deposition on electron microscopy: This is characteristic of membranous nephropathy. In this condition, subepithelial immune deposits lead to the formation of "spikes" on the glomerular basement membrane (GBM) when viewed with silver stain on light microscopy, and the "dome" represents the immune complex deposits seen on electron microscopy. This finding is consistent with the nephrotic syndrome in the context of the patient's colon cancer.

 

Option B. A tram-track pattern on light microscopy: This pattern is typical of membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN), which presents with mesangial proliferation and double contouring of the GBM. MPGN is more commonly associated with nephritic syndrome, complement disorders, or chronic infections and is less likely in this case.

 

Option C. Lumpy subepithelial deposits on electron microscopy: Lumpy deposits are more commonly seen in post-infectious glomerulonephritis, which typically presents as an acute nephritic syndrome following a streptococcal infection, not a nephrotic syndrome in the context of malignancy.

 

Option D. Nonlinear mesangial staining with IgA immunofluorescence: This finding would be indicative of IgA nephropathy (Berger's disease), which primarily presents with episodic hematuria, often following respiratory or gastrointestinal infections, and is not typically associated with nephrotic syndrome or secondary to malignancies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To recognize the association between nephrotic syndrome and secondary causes, such as malignancy, and to understand the characteristic biopsy findings in membranous nephropathy, including the spike-and-dome pattern on electron microscopy. Identifying the underlying cause of nephrotic syndrome is crucial for appropriate management and treatment.

choices.text: Brachioradialis muscle of non-dominant forearm
Brachioradialis muscle of dominant forearm
All 4 glands are reimplanted in normal anatomical locations

questions.text: A 67-year-old male underwent a total thyroidectomy for papillary carcinoma of the thyroid gland. The parathyroid glands were accidentally removed. Where can the surgeon re-implant these glands?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sternocleidomastoid

 

Option A: Brachioradialis muscle of non-dominant forearm - While this is a common site for auto-transplantation in the case of parathyroidectomy for hyperparathyroidism, it is not the typical site for re-implantation following accidental removal during thyroidectomy.

 

Option B: Brachioradialis muscle of dominant forearm - The non-dominant forearm is preferred in parathyroidectomy for hyperplasia to avoid any potential functional impairment in the patient's dominant arm.

 

Option C: Sternocleidomastoid - This is the correct answer. If the parathyroid glands are accidentally removed during thyroid surgery, they can be re-implanted into the sternocleidomastoid muscle. This keeps the parathyroid tissue in the neck, allowing for a more physiological parathyroid function and potentially easier surgical access if there are problems in the future.

 

Option D: All 4 glands are reimplanted in normal anatomical locations - While this might seem ideal, re-implanting the glands back into their normal anatomical locations is not usually feasible or successful because the original vascular supply has been disrupted.

 

Educational Objective: If the parathyroid glands are inadvertently removed during thyroidectomy, they may be re-implanted into the sternocleidomastoid muscle to maintain more physiological parathyroid function and allow for surgical accessibility if needed in the future.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a history of chronic constipation and gastroparesis is seeking medical attention. The physician plans to initiate prokinetic therapy to alleviate the gastrointestinal motility issues. During the consultation, the patient inquires about the different classes of prokinetic drugs and their mechanisms of action. Which of the following drugs should the physician explain is NOT classified as a prokinetic drug?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Diphenoxymethane

 

Explanation for each option:

 

Option D: Diphenoxymethane is not a prokinetic drug. It is the active metabolite of diphenoxylate. It slows the motility of the intestinal tract by binding to the mu-opioid receptors in the intestinal wall, which results in an increase in intestinal transit time and a decrease in fluid secretion.

 

Option A: 5-HT4 agonists like mosapride are prokinetic drugs that act on the 5HT4 receptors in the GI tract to stimulate peristalsis and increase gastric emptying.

 

Option B: D2 blockers such as metoclopramide and domperidone are commonly used as prokinetic drugs due to their ability to increase gastrointestinal motility.

 

Option C: Macrolides are a group of antibiotics that have been shown to have prokinetic effects. They act by binding to motilin receptors in the gut and stimulating gastric motility.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman undergoes general anesthesia for an elective cholecystectomy. The anesthesiologist decides to use neuromuscular monitoring to assess the depth of neuromuscular blockade to ensure adequate muscle relaxation throughout the procedure. As the surgical procedure comes to an end, the anesthesiologist prepares to reverse the neuromuscular blockade. He places electrodes and monitors the muscle group that will give the best indication of recovery from neuromuscular blockade. Which muscle group is the anesthesiologist most likely monitoring in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Adductor pollicis muscle

 

Explanation: The adductor pollicis muscle is commonly monitored during neuromuscular blockade as it correlates well with the recovery of diaphragmatic function and is representative of the muscles used for breathing. The ulnar nerve, which innervates this muscle, is easily accessible, and the muscle's response can be measured using a peripheral nerve stimulator.

 

Option B. The orbicularis oculi muscle is not the best indicator for the depth of neuromuscular blockade in relation to the recovery of respiratory function, as it recovers from neuromuscular blockade earlier than the adductor pollicis.

 

Option C. The masseter muscle is not typically used for monitoring neuromuscular blockade as its response does not correlate well with the muscles used for respiration.

 

Option A. The abductor hallucis muscle is less commonly used and is not as practical for continuous monitoring as the adductor pollicis.

 

Educational Objective: The adductor pollicis muscle is a preferred site for monitoring the recovery from neuromuscular blockade.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presents to the clinic with a 3-month history of fever, night sweats, and unintentional weight loss. On further investigation, he is diagnosed with HIV infection. The patient's CD4 count is 150 cells/mm³, and his viral load is high. The attending doctor explains to the patient that antiretroviral therapy (ART) is necessary to control his HIV infection and prevent the progression to AIDS. He prescribes a combination of ART drugs, including a protease inhibitor. Which of the following is a protease inhibitor?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Saquinavir

 

Explanation:

 

The names of all HIV protease inhibitors end with ‘NAVIR’ e.g., saquinavir, atazanavir etc.

 

Anti-retroviral Drugs

questions.text: Identify the instrument in the picture below.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Indirect laryngoscopy mirror

 

The instrument shown in the image is used for indirect visualization of the larynx and is known as an indirect laryngoscopy mirror.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hypopharyngeal mirror: This would be used to visualize the hypopharynx, the area below the oropharynx and above the esophagus and larynx. While similar in appearance, these mirrors are typically larger to accommodate the broader viewing area required.

 

Option B. Indirect laryngoscopy mirror: This is the correct answer. The mirror shown is used for indirect laryngoscopy, which is a method used to visualize a patient's vocal cords and glottis. It is a small, round mirror attached to a long handle. The mirror is warmed and placed at the back of the throat to visualize the larynx.

 

Option C. Nasopharyngeal mirror: This type of mirror would be used to examine the nasopharynx, the upper part of the throat behind the nose. However, nasopharyngeal mirrors are typically smaller and may have a different shape to navigate through the nasal passages.

 

 

Option D. Direct laryngoscopy mirror: Direct laryngoscopy does not typically use a mirror; it involves using a laryngoscope to directly visualize the larynx. The laryngoscope has a light and a camera at the end, and it is inserted past the back of the throat.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The instrument in the image is an indirect laryngoscopy mirror, used to examine the vocal cords and glottis by reflecting an image to the examiner when placed at the back of the throat.

questions.text: A medical student is reviewing the incubation periods of various sexually transmitted infections (STIs). Match the following STIs to their respective incubation periods.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1-d, 2-c, 3-e, 4-b, 5-a, 6-f

 

Explanation

 

  1. Syphilis - D. 9–90 days
  2. Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV) - C. 3–12 days
  3. Donovanosis - E. 3–21 days
  4. Chancroid - B. 3–5 days
  5. Gonorrhea - A. 1–5 days
  6. Molluscum contagiosum - F. 14–50 days

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following diuretics does not require its presence in the tubular lumen for its pharmacological effects?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Aldosterone antagonists

 

Explanation:

 

  • Aldosterone antagonists like spironolactone do not act through the luminal side rather they act from the basolateral side of the membrane as it acts on the receptors present inside the cells of collecting duct. Therefore, these agents do not require access to the tubular lumen. These are secreted inside the cells of collecting duct from the blood.
  •  Most of the diuretics act from the luminal side of the membrane in the nephron.
  • Thiazides, loop diuretics, carbonic anhydrase inhibitors and epithelial Na+ channel blockers (e.g., amiloride and triamterene) are secreted in the proximal tubules through organic anion/ cation transport process.
  • Osmotic diuretics reach the lumen of proximal tubules via glomerular filtration.
  • All these diuretics (thiazides, loop diuretics, carbonic anhydrase inhibitors, osmotic diuretics, and epithelial Na+ channel blockers) act on the ion channels present on the luminal side of the membranes of nephron.

choices.text: Influenza B

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) visits his primary care physician for an annual check-up. The physician recommends an influenza vaccine. The patient inquires about the strains of influenza covered by the trivalent influenza vaccine. The physician explains that the vaccine typically includes coverage for three specific strains. Based on your knowledge of the trivalent influenza vaccine, which of the following strains is NOT typically included in this vaccine?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) H2N1

 

Explanation

 

TRIVALENT FLU VACCINE

 

  • Type: Inactivated Influenza vaccine
  • Protection:
    • Two Influenza A viruses (an H1N1 and an H3N2)
    • An Influenza B virus
  • Types of Trivalent vaccine:
    • Standard-dose trivalent shots: Approved for people of different ages
    • High-dose trivalent shot: Approved for people 65 years and older
    • Trivalent shot: Approved for people 18 years and older
    • Recombinant trivalent shot: Approved for people 18 years and older

 

Other options - 

 

Option A. H1N1: This strain is commonly included in the influenza vaccine as it is one of the predominant circulating strains of Influenza A.

 

Option C. H3N2: Similar to H1N1, H3N2 is another commonly included strain in the influenza vaccine due to its prevalence.

 

Option D. Influenza B: The vaccine often contains one or two strains of Influenza B, reflecting the circulating strains of this subtype.

 

Educational Objective - 

 

The Trivalent Flu Vaccine is an inactivated vaccine protecting against two Influenza A strains (H1N1, H3N2) and one Influenza B strain. It comes in various forms, including standard-dose shots for all ages, high-dose shots for those 65 years and older, and recombinant shots for adults 18 years and older, addressing diverse age-specific needs.

choices.text: Elevated serum cortisol
Decreased serum potassium
Increased urine homovanillic acid
Increased plasma renin

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is noted to have abdominal enlargement on a visit to the pediatrician. The physical examination is otherwise unremarkable. An abdominal CT scan shows a right upper quadrant mass. The gross appearance of the mass is seen here. Which of the following laboratory test findings is most likely to be present in this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increased urine homovanillic acid

 

Explanation for each option:

 

Option C. Increased urine homovanillic acid:

 

  • Increased urine homovanillic acid (HVA) levels can be indicative of neuroblastoma, a pediatric tumor of the sympathetic nervous system. Neuroblastomas can present as abdominal masses and may lead to the increased excretion of catecholamine metabolites like HVA.

 

Option A. Elevated serum cortisol:

 

  • Elevated serum cortisol levels are typically associated with conditions such as Cushing's syndrome, which is characterized by an excess of cortisol production. This condition is unlikely to be related to the right upper quadrant mass seen in the child.

 

Option B. Decreased serum potassium:

 

  • Decreased serum potassium levels can be a sign of hypokalemia. While hypokalemia can occur in various conditions, it is not specifically associated with a right upper quadrant mass.

 

Option D. Increased plasma renin:

 

  • Increased plasma renin levels can be seen in cases of renal artery stenosis or conditions that lead to reduced renal blood flow. It is not directly related to a right upper quadrant mass.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neuroblastoma is a pediatric tumor that arises from the sympathetic nervous system, often presenting as an abdominal mass. Increased levels of urine catecholamine metabolites, such as homovanillic acid (HVA), can be observed in patients with neuroblastoma. Diagnosis and appropriate management are essential in pediatric oncology to optimize outcomes for children with such tumors.

questions.text:
A medical researcher is analyzing a large data set to understand the distribution of systolic blood pressure readings among a group of patients with hypertension. The researcher aims to apply the appropriate statistical tests to determine if the data follow a normal distribution, which is a crucial assumption for many parametric statistical tests. Given the importance of selecting the right method to assess normality, which combination of graphical and statistical tools should the researcher employ to comprehensively evaluate the normality of the blood pressure readings?

 

  1. Histogram
  2. Box and whisker plot
  3. Shapiro wilk test
  4. Q-Q plot
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

Explanation

 

The correct combination of tools includes both graphical methods (Histogram, Box and Whisker Plot, Q-Q Plot) and a statistical test (Shapiro-Wilk Test) to assess the normality of the data.

 

  • Histograms provide a visual representation of the data's distribution and can reveal the shape of the distribution at a glance.
  • Box and Whisker Plots show the central tendency, dispersion, and skewness in the data, which can indicate deviations from normality.
  • Shapiro-Wilk Test is a powerful statistical test specifically designed to test the null hypothesis that a sample comes from a normally distributed population.
  • Q-Q Plots compare the quantiles of the sample to the quantiles of a normal distribution, providing a visual means to assess deviations from normality.

 

Educational Objective

 

Methods available to test the normality of the continuous data

 

  • Shapiro–Wilk test
  • Kolmogorov–Smirnov test
  • Skewness, Kurtosis
  • Histogram,
  • Box plot
  • P–P Plot, Q–Q Plot
  • Mean with SD

choices.text: Arthroscopic debridement of the shoulder
Reverse total arthroplasty of the shoulder
Open repair of the rotator cuff

questions.text: A 77-year-old man is referred to the clinic by his primary care provider because he has pain in his left shoulder that has been worsening over the past six months. The patient says the pain has progressed to the extent that he can no longer play golf or enjoy his hobby of cabinet making. He has been treated with one injection of a corticosteroid and has been compliant with physical therapy for the past three months, but he has not had significant relief of his pain. He has no history of injury to the shoulder. On physical examination, range of motion of the shoulder shows forward flexion and abduction to 75 degrees. X-ray study of the shoulder is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Reverse total arthroplasty of the shoulder

 

Explanation for each option:

 

Option B. Reverse Total Arthroplasty of the Shoulder: Given the patient's age, the severity and duration of symptoms, the lack of significant relief from conservative management (corticosteroid injection and physical therapy), and his functional limitations, the most appropriate next step is likely Reverse Total Arthroplasty of the Shoulder. This option is especially relevant if the X-ray indicates severe arthritis or a complex rotator cuff tear, which are common in this age group and present similarly to the patient's symptoms. This surgical procedure involves replacing the shoulder joint with a prosthesis, with the ball and socket reversed from their natural positions. It is particularly effective in treating severe shoulder arthritis, especially in patients with concomitant rotator cuff tears where conventional total shoulder arthroplasty might not be as effective.

 

Option A. Arthroscopic Debridement of the Shoulder: This procedure involves the removal of damaged tissue from the shoulder joint. It can be beneficial in cases of mild to moderate osteoarthritis or rotator cuff tears. However, its effectiveness may be limited in more severe cases, especially if there is significant joint damage or a large rotator cuff tear.

 

Option C. Hemiarthroplasty of the Shoulder: This is a partial shoulder replacement, where only the humeral head is replaced. It can be considered in cases of severe shoulder arthritis with an intact rotator cuff. However, its effectiveness can be less in the presence of a rotator cuff tear or advanced joint disease.

 

Option D. Open Repair of the Rotator Cuff: This involves surgically repairing torn rotator cuff tendons. This option is considered when there is a significant rotator cuff tear, but it may not be as effective in older patients with advanced shoulder arthritis and severe rotator cuff degeneration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In elderly patients with severe shoulder pain, limited range of motion, and failure to respond to conservative treatment, reverse total arthroplasty is often the most effective management, particularly in the presence of severe arthritis and/or significant rotator cuff pathology. This procedure can provide substantial pain relief and functional improvement, especially in those with complex shoulder conditions.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient with a long history of severe eosinophilic asthma presents to the clinic. Despite being treated with high-dose inhaled corticosteroids and long-acting beta-agonists, she continues to have frequent asthma exacerbations requiring systemic corticosteroids. After further evaluation, the physician decides to initiate a monoclonal antibody therapy that targets IL-5R. Which of the following medications targets IL-5R and works by antibody-dependent cell-mediated cytotoxicity (ADCC)?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Benralizumab

 

Explanation for each option:

 

Option C. Benralizumab

 

  • Benralizumab is a monoclonal antibody targeting IL-5R (IL-5 receptor) and exerts its effects through antibody-dependent cell-mediated cytotoxicity (ADCC).

 

Option A. Reslizumab

 

  • Reslizumab is a monoclonal antibody that targets IL-5 but does not work through antibody-dependent cell-mediated cytotoxicity (ADCC).

 

Option B. Mepolizumab

 

  • Mepolizumab is another monoclonal antibody targeting IL-5, but it does not primarily work through ADCC.

 

Option D. Lebrikizumab

 

  • Lebrikizumab is another monoclonal antibody that targets IL-13 and does not primarily work through ADCC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Benralizumab is a novel therapy for severe eosinophilic asthma. It binds to the IL-5 receptor (IL-5R) on the surface of eosinophils, leading to their destruction through ADCC. This reduces eosinophilic inflammation and helps prevent asthma exacerbations in patients with severe eosinophilic asthma.

questions.text: You are attending physiology viva. The examiner asks you “Who recorded the first EEG?”. You say "I don't know." The examiner feels bad for you and gives you a clue that "the name sounds like something you get commonly in McDonalds". You remember the name and answer correctly. What type of memory has been implicated here?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Priming

 

Explanation:

 

Priming is when exposure to a stimulus influences the response to a subsequent stimulus. In this scenario, the examiner's hint about McDonald's (suggesting "burger") facilitated the student's recall of "Berger," who recorded the first EEG.

 

Option A. Semantic memory involves facts and general knowledge, like knowing the capital of a country.

 

Option B. Implicit memory is unconscious, but involves skills or tasks, like riding a bike.

 

Option C. Associative learning involves pairing two stimuli, like Pavlov's dog experiment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Priming means that a recent experience makes it easier for you to notice or identify something related.

 

Perceptual Priming: Recognizing something becomes easier because you've recently seen something that looks similar. For example, if you've just seen a picture of a lion, you'll be faster at spotting the word "lion" even if it's a bit unclear.

 

Conceptual Priming: Understanding or noticing something becomes easier because you've recently thought about a related idea. For example, if you've just read about rivers and banks, you'll probably guess the word "bank" when given "ban_" instead of thinking of "band."

choices.text: Islands of sparing over body

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the Derma OPD with thickened palms & Soles. These lesions were insidious in onset. He was diagnosed with Pityriasis Rubra Pilaris. Which of the following features is most likely to be found in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Islands of sparing over body

 

The correct answer is option C. Islands of sparing over body

 

Let’s discuss all the options:

 

Option C. Islands of sparing over body

 

Features of PRP:

 

  • Dry scaly plaques with salmon red or orange red colour are characteristically seen; these plaques coalesce to leave islands of normal skin, commonly referred to as islands of sparing, between the lesions.
  • Trunk: the most typical location.
  • The image below shows islands of sparing in pityriasis rubra pilaris.

 

 

  • Follicular hyperkeratosis causes nutmeg grater papules to appear on the elbow and wrist.
  • Palmoplantar keratoderma causes keratoderma on the sole to be so thick that it resembles a sandal.

 

 

  • Thickened, discoloured nails that are distally showing splinter haemorrhages.

 

Option A. Nail pitting

 

  • It is commonly seen in psoriasis, not typically in PRP.
  • While nail changes can occur in PRP, they are not as characteristic as the islands of sparing.

 

Option B. Pterygium

 

  • This is a finding more commonly associated with lichen planus and involves the progression of skin to encroach upon the nails, which is not a feature of PRP.

 

Option D. Herald patch

 

  • It is associated with Pityriasis Rosea, a different condition that presents with a large, solitary patch followed by a generalized body rash, not typically seen in PRP.
  • Educational Objective:
  • Recognize islands of sparing as a distinctive clinical sign in patients with Pityriasis Rubra Pilaris, which can aid in differentiating it from other erythrodermic skin diseases.

 

Reference: Rook’s textbook of dermatology, 9th Edition, Chapter 36, page no. 36.1–36.4

Online Resource: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2783063/

choices.text: The bowel is covered by 3 layers.
Frequently associated with syndromes.
Musculoskeletal anomalies are the most common associated defects.
Exomphalos major requires staged repair.

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement about the condition in the image.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Musculoskeletal anomalies are the most common associated defects

 

The condition depicted above is called Exomphalos.

 

Lets evaluate each option :

 

Option A. The bowel is covered by 3 layers: This is correct. In exomphalos (also known as omphalocele), the herniated abdominal contents are covered by a sac composed of the peritoneum, Wharton's jelly, and amnion.

 

Option B. Frequently associated with syndromes: This is also correct. Exomphalos can be associated with chromosomal abnormalities and various syndromes, particularly when the defect is large.

 

Option C. Musculoskeletal anomalies are the most common associated defects: This statement is incorrect for exomphalos. The most common defects associated with exomphalos are cardiac malformations, not musculoskeletal anomalies.

 

Option D. Exomphalos major requires staged repair: This is correct. In cases of exomphalos major where the defect is large (>5 cm), often involving the liver, a staged repair or non-operative management allowing for epithelialization before closure is typically required.

 

Educational Objective: In exomphalos, also known as omphalocele, the herniated bowel is covered by a three-layered sac, with cardiac anomalies being more common than musculoskeletal defects, and larger defects may require a staged surgical approach.

choices.text: Increased partial pressure of carbon dioxide in the blood

questions.text: The oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve represents the percent saturation of hemoglobin with oxygen as a function of the partial pressure of oxygen in the blood. This curve is sigmoidal in shape due to the change in affinity of heme groups for additional oxygen molecules. Which of the following in an adult would cause a shift in the curve so that it resembles that of a neonate?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increased pH

 

Explanation for each option:

 

Option C. Increased pH: An increase in pH, or alkalosis, would cause a leftward shift in the curve, indicating an increased affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen. This shift would make the curve more similar to that of a neonate, as it would mean that at any given partial pressure of oxygen, hemoglobin would be more saturated with oxygen, similar to the higher oxygen affinity seen with fetal hemoglobin.

 

Option A. Increased 2,3-diphosphoglycerate (2,3-DPG): This would actually cause a rightward shift in the curve, indicating a decreased affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen, which is the opposite of what is seen in neonates.

 

Option B.
