questions.text: A 2-year-old Male child was brought by her parents with delayed developmental milestones and pain in lower limbs and difficulty in walking for 3 months. O/E, child had stiffness of joints in both upper and lower limbs and has coarse facial features, low IQ and hepatomegaly. Urinary examination reveals presence of heparan sulfate and dermatan sulphate. Fibroblast study reveals deficiency of enzyme iduronate sulfatase. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hunters Disease

Hunter Syndrome (Mucopolysaccharidosis Type II): Deficiency of iduronate sulfatase, C/F-  MR, Skeletal deformity, deafness, no corneal clouding with Dermatan Sulfate (DS) and Heparan Sulfate in urine.     
 

 

Other Options:

 

False: Option (a) Maroteaux-Lamy disease: Deficiency of N-Acetyl-D-Galactosamine-4- Sulfatase. C/F: Skeletal deformity, corneal opacity, No MR and Dermatan Sulfate in urine.

 

False: Option (c) Hurlers disease: is due to the deficiency of enzyme -L Iduronidase causes accumulation of dermatan sulphate and heparan sulphate. C/F: Mental retardation, coarse facial features, hepatosplenomegaly, cloudy cornea

 

False: Option (d) Scheies disease: Deficiency of L-Iduronidase. C/F: No MR with mild skeletal changes, corneal opacity and DS in urine.

 

Ref: Harper, 30th edition, page no. 638-639; Nelson, 20th edition, Tables 82.1 and 82.2

questions.text: A 27-year-old man presents with four days of progressive, bilateral, lower extremity weakness and dysesthesia. The patient denies any history of trauma, but states that he stayed home from work last week because of fever accompanied by diarrhea. Neurologic examination demonstrates the absence of reflexes in the lower extremities with no cranial nerve deficits. What is the best therapy for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Plasmapheresis and immunoglobulin

 

Explanation for each option:

 

Option A. Plasmapheresis and immunoglobulin: This is the correct answer. Both plasmapheresis (plasma exchange) and intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) are established treatments for Guillain-Barré syndrome. These therapies are thought to modulate the immune response and remove pathogenic antibodies and other immune mediators from the circulation, which can help halt the progression of the disease and potentially speed up recovery. The choice between plasmapheresis and IVIG is often based on availability, medical comorbidities, and patient preference, as they are considered equally effective for GBS.

 

Option B. Glucocorticoids: While glucocorticoids are commonly used to treat a variety of autoimmune and inflammatory conditions, they have not been shown to be effective in the treatment of Guillain-Barré syndrome and are not recommended as a treatment for GBS.

 

Option C. Acetaminophen: While acetaminophen can be used to manage fever and mild pain, it does not address the underlying immune-mediated process of Guillain-Barré syndrome and is not considered a treatment for the condition itself.

 

Option D. Radiation therapy: Radiation therapy is a treatment modality used primarily for cancer and certain non-malignant conditions, but it is not a treatment for Guillain-Barré syndrome, which is an autoimmune disorder affecting the peripheral nervous system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To recognize the clinical presentation of Guillain-Barré syndrome and understand the appropriate treatment options. Guillain-Barré syndrome is an acute, immune-mediated polyneuropathy that can follow infectious illnesses, and prompt treatment with either plasmapheresis or intravenous immunoglobulin can improve outcomes by modulating the immune response.

questions.text:
Which of the following medical procedures would require the use of the instrument shown in the image?

 

 

 

  1. To hold the fundus of the gall bladder
  2. To hold drapes in surgical field
  3. To grasp the products of conception
  4. To hold the spermatic cord
  5. To hold the cervix
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1 and 5

 

Explanation:


Sponge holding forceps, as depicted in the image, are versatile surgical instruments with various applications. They are commonly used to:

 

  1. Clean skin: They are employed to clean the skin using a swab dipped in antiseptic solution before and during surgical procedures to maintain a sterile field.
  2. Remove laminated membrane and daughter cysts: During the surgical treatment of hydatid cyst, these forceps are utilized to delicately remove laminated membranes and daughter cysts.
  3. Open Cholecystectomy: They play a crucial role in holding and manipulating the fundus and Hartmann's pouch of the gall bladder during cholecystectomy surgeries.
  4. Swab abscess cavity: Sponge holding forceps are used to swab and clean abscess cavities, ensuring thorough disinfection and drainage.
  5. Cerclage: In obstetrics, these forceps can be employed to hold the cervix in place during cerclage procedures, providing precise control and support.

 

Educational objective: Sponge holding forceps are essential tools in the surgical and medical field, facilitating various procedures and ensuring patient safety and successful outcomes.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman comes to her family physician for a routine check-up. She exhibits mild mental retardation. Physical examination shows an oval-shaped, slightly pigmented nevus on the lower back and an angiofibroma on the forehead that the patient reports having had since birth. The patient has a history of a cardiac rhabdomyoma that spontaneously regressed in childhood. A previous MRI showed multiple nodules of glial proliferation in the basal ganglia, ventricles, and cortex. This patient most likely also has which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Epilepsy

 

The clinical presentation described is consistent with tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC), a genetic disorder characterized by the growth of noncancerous (benign) tumors in many parts of the body, including the skin, brain, kidneys, and heart. Common manifestations include skin abnormalities such as hypomelanotic macules (which might resemble the described nevus) and facial angiofibromas, as well as neurological symptoms due to brain involvement, such as the mentioned glial nodules.

 

Explanation for each option:

 

Option C. Epilepsy: Given the patient's history and clinical features suggestive of tuberous sclerosis complex, the most likely associated condition she also has is Epilepsy. This is a common neurological manifestation of TSC, affecting up to 90% of individuals with the condition. The presence of multiple nodules of glial proliferation in the brain, as mentioned, can lead to seizures, making epilepsy a likely associated condition.

 

Option A. Bilateral hearing loss: While TSC can affect various organs, it is not typically associated with bilateral hearing loss as a direct consequence of the disease.

 

Option B. Central scotoma: A central scotoma is a loss of vision in the central visual field, which can occur in various eye diseases but is not a hallmark feature of TSC.

 

Option D. Severe sun sensitivity: While some skin manifestations in TSC may be exacerbated by sun exposure, severe sun sensitivity is not a characteristic feature of this condition, as it would be in disorders specifically affecting DNA repair mechanisms in response to UV light, such as xeroderma pigmentosum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To recognize the clinical features of tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC) and its neurological manifestations. TSC is a genetic disorder that can cause benign tumors in multiple organs, including the brain, where they can lead to epilepsy. Understanding the multi-organ involvement of TSC is crucial for diagnosis, management, and surveillance for associated complications, including seizures.

choices.text: Acute rheumatic fever
Intravenous drug use
Congenital bicuspid valve
Trousseau syndrome

questions.text: After a high fever for 4 days, a 27-year-old man becomes delirious, and his friends bring him to the emergency room. Physical examination reveals a cardiac murmur, along with splenomegaly and a temperature of 38.7°C. Splinter hemorrhages appear under the nails of both his hands. Echocardiography reveals the lesions seen here. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Intravenous drug use

 

Explanation for each option:

 

Option B. Intravenous drug use:

 

  • Intravenous drug use is associated with an increased risk of infective endocarditis, which is an infection of the heart valves or lining of the heart. It is often caused by bacteria entering the bloodstream through contaminated needles or paraphernalia. Patients with infective endocarditis can present with cardiac murmurs, splenomegaly, and other systemic symptoms, making this option a likely diagnosis.

 

Option A. Acute rheumatic fever:

 

  • Acute rheumatic fever is an autoimmune inflammatory condition that can affect various parts of the body, including the heart. It typically occurs as a result of untreated streptococcal throat infections (streptococcal pharyngitis). It can lead to carditis (inflammation of the heart), which may result in heart murmurs and other cardiac manifestations. However, the presentation in this case does not fit the typical pattern of acute rheumatic fever.

 

Option C. Congenital bicuspid valve:

 

  • A congenital bicuspid valve is a heart valve anomaly in which the aortic valve has two leaflets instead of the normal three. While bicuspid valves can be prone to dysfunction and may require surgical intervention, they are not typically associated with the specific findings seen in this patient's case, such as splinter hemorrhages and intracardiac lesions.

 

Option D. Trousseau syndrome:

 

  • Trousseau syndrome, also known as migratory thrombophlebitis, is a condition characterized by recurrent thrombophlebitis (inflammation of veins) and is often associated with an underlying malignancy. It does not typically involve cardiac lesions or endocarditis-related symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Intravenous drug use is a significant risk factor for the development of infective endocarditis, a condition characterized by infection of the heart valves or lining of the heart. Prompt diagnosis and treatment are crucial to prevent complications associated with infective endocarditis.

questions.text: A woman underwent a gastrectomy procedure 5 months ago for the presence of a gastric ulcer. She now complains of exertional breathlessness. Her blood picture is as follows. What supplements do you think she needs?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Iron

 

The clinical scenario is suggestive of iron deficiency anemia and therefore, the patient has to be supplemented with iron.

 

The blood picture suggests microcytic anemia, which is characterized by red blood cells that are smaller than normal and typically indicates iron deficiency anemia.

 

Let's evaluate the supplement options:

 

Option A: Iron. True. After gastrectomy, patients are at risk for iron deficiency anemia due to decreased stomach acid, which is necessary for iron absorption, and the removal of the duodenum, a primary site of iron absorption.

 

Option B: Calcium. False. While calcium absorption can be affected by gastrectomy due to alterations in the digestive process and the need for vitamin D, the blood picture provided does not specifically suggest a calcium deficiency.

 

Option C: Cobalamin (Vitamin B12). False. Vitamin B12 deficiency anemia typically presents as macrocytic anemia, with larger than normal red blood cells. However, vitamin B12 deficiency is a concern after gastrectomy due to the loss of intrinsic factor produced by the stomach, which is necessary for vitamin B12 absorption. It usually takes longer to develop after surgery due to large body stores of vitamin B12.

 

Option D: Folic acid. False. Folic acid deficiency also typically presents with macrocytic anemia, not microcytic anemia. It is less likely to be immediately deficient following gastrectomy compared to iron.

 

Given that the blood picture shows features suggestive of iron deficiency anemia, the correct supplement needed is Option A: Iron.

 

Educational Objective: After gastrectomy, patients are at an increased risk for iron deficiency anemia due to reduced absorption. Supplementing with iron can help correct the anemia and improve symptoms such as exertional breathlessness.

choices.text: Alcoholic hallucinosis
Brief psychotic disorder
Cocaine withdrawal
Delirium tremens

questions.text: A 42-year-old man is admitted to the hospital after sustaining fractures of his right femur and tibia in a motor vehicle collision. The Patient becomes agitated, hypervigilant, and paranoid 12 hours after admission. He Repeatedly tells the nurses that he can hear people in the corridor making insulting remarks about him. When hospital staff check the area near the patient's room, no one is found. Medical history is unremarkable, but psychiatric history is significant for cocaine, marijuana, and alcohol misuse. He has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes a day for the past 10 years. On examination, the patient is alert and oriented. Temperature is 37.2C (99F), blood pressure is 135/87 mm Hg, pulse is 85/min, and respirations are 18/min. He is slightly tremulous and diaphoretic. Within 2 days, the patient's hallucinations resolve, and his behavior returns to baseline. Soon after, he is discharged home. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Alcoholic hallucinosis

 

Explanation for each option:

 

Option A: Alcoholic hallucinosis. This patient's history of alcohol misuse, lack of premorbid psychosis, and acute onset of auditory hallucinations shortly after hospitalization (i.e., with abrupt cessation of alcohol) are most consistent with alcoholic hallucinosis. Alcoholic hallucinosis is an alcohol withdrawal syndrome characterized by hallucinations and relatively stable vital signs in an otherwise alert and oriented patient. Alcoholic hallucinosis typically presents after 12 hours of abstinence and resolves within 48 hours after the last drink. The condition is usually self-limited but can be managed with benzodiazepines.

 

Option B: Brief psychotic disorder is characterized by sudden-onset psychotic symptoms lasting ≥1 day and ≤1 month. It isa rare disorder that can be diagnosed only after psychosis due to substance intoxication/withdrawal or a medical condition is ruled out. This patient's onset of hallucinations 12 hours following hospitalization, along with a history of alcohol abuse, is more suggestive of alcohol withdrawal-induced psychosis (i.e., alcoholic hallucinosis).

 

Option C: Cocaine withdrawal causes depression, anxiety, fatigue, and intense cravings. It is not commonly associated with psychosis.

 

Option D: Delirium tremens, which does not present prior to 48 hours after the last drink, is characterized by disorientation and marked sympathetic hyperactivity (e.g., hyperthermia, hypertension, tachycardia). This patient is alert and oriented, his vital signs are normal, and his hallucinations fully resolved before 48hours (i.e., hospital day 2).

 

Educational objective:

 

Alcoholic hallucinosis is an alcohol withdrawal syndrome that typically present after 12 hours of abstinence and resolves within 48 hours after the last drink. Unlike delirium tremens, it tends to present in patients who are fully oriented and with relatively stable vital signs.

questions.text: In a hospital laboratory setting, proper disposal of medical waste is paramount to ensuring safety and preventing contamination. A new laboratory technician is being trained on the protocols for disposing of various types of laboratory waste, including used vacutainers which are commonly used for blood collection. The technician learns that different colors of disposal containers and bags are designated for specific types of waste according to standard biomedical waste management guidelines. Based on these guidelines, in which of the following disposal containers should used vacutainers be discarded?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Red bag

 

Explanation:

 

Red category contains Contaminated Waste (Recyclable) including wastes generated from disposable items such as vacutainers but without needles.

 

BMW category

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Under NEW Biomedical Waste Management Guidelines 2016-17, Red bag is used for disposal of Contaminated Waste (Recyclable)

 

It includes wastes generated from disposable items such as tubing, bottles, intravenous tubes and sets, catheters, urine bags, syringes (without needles and fixed needle syringes) and vaccutainers (with their needles cut) and gloves

choices.text: Cristae of superior semicircular canal
Cristae of lateral semicircular canal

questions.text: An ENT Surgeon while doing singular neurectomy for intractable BPPV, has cut its parent nerve accidentally. Which other structure is supposed to lose its sensory supply now, apart from posterior semicircular canal?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Macule of saccule

 

When considering the surgical procedure of singular neurectomy aimed at treating intractable benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV), an unintended cut of its parent nerve would affect the sensory innervation of structures within the inner ear. The singular nerve, primarily responsible for innervating the posterior semicircular canal, originates from the vestibular division of the vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII). The question at hand focuses on what other structure would lose its sensory supply if the parent nerve of the singular nerve is accidentally cut.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cristae of superior semicircular canal: The cristae of the superior semicircular canal are innervated by the superior vestibular nerve, a branch of the vestibulocochlear nerve. This structure would not be directly affected by a singular neurectomy.

 

Option B. Cristae of lateral semicircular canal: The cristae of the lateral semicircular canal are also innervated by the superior vestibular nerve. Thus, it would not lose sensory supply due to injury to the nerve associated with the singular nerve.

 

Option C. Macula of saccule: The macula of the saccule is innervated by the inferior vestibular nerve, the same division of the vestibulocochlear nerve as the singular nerve. The saccule is sensitive to vertical acceleration and gravity. If the parent nerve of the singular nerve is cut, it implies that the inferior vestibular nerve is compromised, affecting the macula of the saccule.

 

 

Option D. Macula of utricle: The macula of the utricle is primarily innervated by the superior vestibular nerve. It is responsible for sensing horizontal acceleration. This structure would not be affected by damage to the singular nerve or its parent nerve within the context of the inferior vestibular nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the context of singular neurectomy for intractable BPPV, accidental cutting of its parent nerve (the inferior vestibular nerve) would lead to a loss of sensory supply to the macula of the saccule, in addition to the posterior semicircular canal. This educational objective underscores the importance of understanding the innervation of the inner ear structures.

choices.text: Iron deficiency anemia
G6PD deficiency anemia
Vitamin B12 deficiency

questions.text: A 29-year-old G2P1 woman at 28 weeks’ gestation, who had normal haemoglobin level 4 weeks ago at her first prenatal visit, complains of 1 week of fatigue and now has a haemoglobin level of 7.0 g/ dL. She noted dark-coloured urine after taking an antibiotic for a urinary tract infection. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) G6PD deficiency anemia

 

  • This 29-year-old woman at 28 weeks’ gestation complains of fatigue. She took an antibiotic for a urinary tract infection and then developed dark-coloured urine. She was also probably icteric. Currently, her Hemoglobin level is low, reflecting anemia.
  • This constellation of symptoms likely reflects a hemolytic process probably due to G6PD deficiency. The dark urine suggests bilirubinuria.
  • Other causes of hemolysis could include malaria, HELLP syndrome, autoimmune hemolytic anemia, or sickle cell crisis. In this case, the woman ingested an antibiotic, which likely was nitrofurantoin, a commonly prescribed medication for pregnant women. She does not have hypertension, symptoms of systemic lupus erythematosus or other autoimmune diseases, or pain suggestive of sickle cell disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) is an enzyme found in the cytoplasm of all cells in the body.
  • It is a housekeeping enzyme that plays a vital role in the prevention of cellular damage from reactive oxygen species (ROS).
  • It does this by providing substrates to prevent oxidative damage.
  • Erythrocytes are particularly vulnerable to ROS due to their role in oxygen transport and inability to replace cellular proteins as mature cells.
  • Inherited deficiencies of G6PD can result in acute hemolytic anemia during times of increased ROS production.
  • This may be caused by stress or exposure to certain foods that contain high amounts of oxidative substances, for example, fava beans, or certain medications (antimalarials, antibiotics etc.). 

 

Ref: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no. 2739

questions.text: A 12-year-old female with an unremarkable past medical history presents with fever, sore throat, and a tender cervical lymphadenopathy. She is diagnosed with streptococcal Group A pharyngitis and is treated with IM penicillin. Within a few minutes of the injection, the patient is dyspneic, tachycardic, and hypotensive, and is noted to have wheezing on examination. She also complains of dysphagia. IM epinephrine is administered immediately. Which adrenoceptor primarily mediates the respiratory system response?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Beta 2

 

Explanation:

 

The patient probably developed anaphylactic shock due to penicillin. Adrenaline is drug of choice for anaphylactic shock.

choices.text: Dandy walker malformation
Arnold Chiari Malformation
Aicardi syndrome

questions.text: A Mother brings her 4-year-old child Ramya with features of intellectual disability and refractory seizures. On evaluation, she had a normal physical appearance. A spine X-ray reveals the presence of Hemivertebrae and the MRI image of the child is given below. What is the likely diagnosis based on the clinical features and the radiological findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Aicardi syndrome

 

  • Aicardi syndrome represents a complex disorder that affects many systems and is typically associated with agenesis of the corpus callosum, distinctive chorio-retinal lacunae, and infantile spasms.
  • Seizures become evident during the 1st few months and are typically resistant to anticonvulsants.
  • An EEG shows independent activity recorded from both hemispheres as a result of the absent corpus callosum and often shows hemihypsarrhythmia.
  • MRI will show the agenesis of Corpus callosum.
  • All patients have severe intellectual disability and can have abnormal vertebrae that may be fused or only partially developed (hemivertebra).
  • Abnormalities of the retina, including circumscribed pits or lacunae and coloboma of the optic disc, are the most characteristic findings of Aicardi syndrome.

 

Option A, B and C doesn’t correlate with the clinical features and the radiological features of Aicardi syndrome.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Aicardi syndrome is diagnosed by symptoms such as intellectual disability and refractory seizures, along with distinctive radiological findings, including hemivertebrae and agenesis of the corpus callosum on MRI.

 

Ref: OP Ghai, 9th Edition, Page No. 557

questions.text: A working mother in a multinational company brings her 3-months old child for a regular pediatric visit. As she has started to go to work after her child birth, she wants to feed her child with cow’s milk. She asks you that compared with cow’s milk, mother’s milk has which component in more quantity?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lactose

 

 

Option B, C and D are present in quantities in cow’s milk when compared to mothers milk.

 

Educational objective:

 

Mother’s milk has more content of lactose than the cow or buffalo milk.

 

Ref: OP Ghai, 9th edition, Page No. 145

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is brought to the emergency department of a district hospital in India with a history of sudden onset muscle weakness, ptosis, and difficulty breathing. He reports being bitten by a snake while walking through his farm at night. The emergency medical officer notes two small puncture wounds on his ankle. The patient's condition rapidly deteriorates, necessitating intubation and mechanical ventilation. The medical officer suspects envenomation by a common Indian krait. Considering the severity of symptoms, what is the estimated lethal dose of krait venom for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 6 mg

 

Explanation

 

Signs and symptoms are similar to cobra poisoning, but less rapid. Abdominal pain, ptosis, dysarthria, dysphagia, chest pain, quadriparesis, respiratory paralysis and death may occur. There is no nausea and froth, but drowsiness is more. Common krait hunt nocturnally and are quick to bite people sleeping on the floor, often without waking their victims since the venom is painless. Bites would show symptoms within the first 6 hr.  Victims wake up later, paralyzed or die in their sleep.

 

Bite mark - Two fang marks, with or without small marks of other teeth. 

 

 

 

Bite Mark

 

Common Krait

 

Krait venom is highly potent, and a dose as low as 6 mg can be lethal in humans. The venom contains neurotoxins that lead to paralysis by blocking neurotransmitter release at the neuromuscular junction.

 

Educational Objective

 

Fatal Doses -

choices.text: Bowel sounds in the left lower lung zone
Midline deviation of the trachea

questions.text: A premature child is born in respiratory distress and is emergently intubated. Synthetic pulmonary surfactant is administered with no improvement in pulmonary function. After conducting a detailed physical examination, the pediatrician believes that this child’s condition is related to a failure of the embryonic pleuroperitoneal folds to form and close. What physical examination finding would support the most likely diagnosis in this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bowel sounds in the left lower lung zone

 

Explanation for each option:

 

Option A. Bowel sounds in the left lower lung zone: This finding would be highly suggestive of CDH, particularly if the defect is on the left side, which is more common. The presence of bowel sounds in the thoracic cavity indicates that abdominal contents have herniated into the chest, displacing lung tissue and contributing to respiratory distress.

 

Option B. Continuous cardiac murmur: A continuous cardiac murmur, often referred to as a "machinery" murmur, is characteristic of a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), a condition in which the ductus arteriosus fails to close after birth. While PDA can be associated with other congenital conditions, it is not specifically indicative of CDH.

 

Option C. Marked splenomegaly: Splenomegaly refers to an enlarged spleen, which can be a sign of various conditions, including hematologic, infectious, or inflammatory diseases, but it is not a typical finding directly associated with CDH.

 

Option D. Midline deviation of the trachea: Tracheal deviation can occur in cases of significant mediastinal shift due to massive pleural effusions, tension pneumothorax, or large masses. While CDH can lead to a shift of mediastinal structures, midline deviation of the trachea is not as specific or as common as hearing bowel sounds in the chest.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To recognize the clinical presentation and diagnostic findings associated with congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH). CDH can lead to respiratory distress in newborns due to the herniation of abdominal organs into the thoracic cavity, which can be suggested by the presence of bowel sounds in the chest on physical examination. Identifying this key finding is crucial for the prompt diagnosis and management of CDH.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient from a tropical country presents to the clinic with complaints of recurrent high fever and progressive swelling of the lower extremities over the past several months. Physical examination reveals significant lymphedema of both legs. Laboratory tests show increased eosinophil count. The patient mentions that these symptoms started after he noticed frequent mosquito bites during his work in rural areas. Based on the patient's history and clinical findings, which worm is most likely responsible for his lymphatic obstruction?
questions.solution:
Ans. A)  Filarial worm

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical presentation of recurrent fever, significant lymphedema in the lower extremities, and a history of mosquito exposure in a tropical country strongly suggests lymphatic filariasis. This condition is commonly caused by the filarial worm, particularly Wuchereria bancrofti, which is transmitted through mosquito bites. The increased eosinophil count supports a parasitic infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hookworm - Hookworms typically cause intestinal symptoms and anemia, not lymphatic obstruction.

 

Option C. Pinworm - Pinworm infection primarily presents with perianal itching, especially in children, and does not cause lymphatic obstruction.

 

Option D. Tapeworm - Tapeworms generally cause gastrointestinal symptoms and, in some cases, systemic infections, but they are not known to cause lymphatic obstruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The clinical presentation of recurrent fever, significant lymphedema in the lower extremities, and a history of mosquito exposure in a tropical country strongly suggests lymphatic filariasis (Wuchereria bancrofti). The increased eosinophil count also supports the diagnosis of a parasitic infection.

choices.text: Parvovirus B-19

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl presents to the pediatric clinic with a facial rash and low-grade fever. Her mother reports that the child has seemed unusually tired over the past few days and has been refusing to eat her normal diet. On examination, the child has a "slapped cheek" appearance with erythema on both cheeks and a reticulated body rash. Laboratory tests reveal a normocytic anemia and a low reticulocyte count. The physician suspects a viral etiology that characteristically affects the erythroid cell line, especially the pronormoblast stage, leading to transient aplastic anemia in children. Which of the following viruses is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Parvovirus B-19

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Parvovirus B19 is the etiological agent for transient aplastic anemia, particularly affecting the erythroid cell line at the pronormoblast stage.

choices.text: >10% population of known HIV +ve among TB patients tested for HIV in the district
>12% population of known HIV +ve among TB patients tested for HIV in the district
>15% population of known HIV +ve among TB patients tested for HIV in the district
>20% population of known HIV +ve among TB patients tested for HIV in the district

questions.text: A public health official is analyzing data from various districts as part of the National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP) to identify regions that require intensified TB-HIV co-infection management strategies. Given the significant overlap between TB and HIV populations, it is crucial to prioritize districts with higher rates of co-infection for targeted interventions. Based on the NTEP guidelines, how is a high priority TB-HIV district defined in terms of the percentage of known HIV-positive cases among TB patients tested for HIV?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) >10% population of known HIV +ve among TB patients tested for HIV in the district

 

Explanation

 

Categorisation of Districts under NTEP (for HIV-TB Co-infection)

 

 

Educational Objective

 

TB and HIV:

 

  • 10% activation of dormant TB over lifetime increases to 10% activation in one year
  • HIV-TB co-infection increases chances of TB disease 25-30 times more than in those infected with TB only
  • Diagnosis problems: Higher chances of Negative sputum smears (Use sputum culture), Chest x-ray less useful, Tuberculin test failure; Extrapulmonary TB more common

questions.text: A 27-year-old man develops acute onset of fever, malaise, muscle pain, hypertension, abdominal pain, bloody stool, and prerenal failure six months after recovering from an acute hepatitis B infection. Which of the following disease processes is most likely responsible for the patient’s findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Polyarteritis nodosa

 

Explanation for each option:

 

Option D. Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN): PAN is a systemic vasculitis of small or medium-sized arteries that can lead to a wide range of symptoms, including fever, malaise, weight loss, hypertension, abdominal pain, and kidney failure. PAN has a known association with hepatitis B infection, making it the most likely diagnosis given this patient's recent history of hepatitis B and the constellation of symptoms. Given the patient's history and symptoms, the most likely diagnosis is Polyarteritis nodosa.

 

Option A. Buerger disease (Thromboangiitis obliterans): This disease primarily affects small and medium-sized arteries and veins in the arms and legs, leading to reduced blood flow. It is strongly associated with tobacco use, not hepatitis B infection, and typically does not present with the systemic symptoms described.

 

Option B. Giant cell (temporal) arteritis: This is a form of large vessel vasculitis that usually affects older adults, typically over 50 years of age, and involves the temporal arteries. Symptoms include headache, jaw claudication, and visual disturbances. It does not typically present with the systemic symptoms seen in this young patient, nor is it associated with hepatitis B infection.

 

Option C. Kawasaki syndrome: This acute febrile illness primarily affects children under five years old and is characterized by fever, rash, conjunctivitis, inflammation of the mouth and throat, swollen hands and feet, and a peeling rash. It does not typically cause the severe multi-organ involvement seen in this patient and is not associated with hepatitis B.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To recognize the clinical presentation and associated conditions of Polyarteritis Nodosa (PAN), a systemic vasculitis that affects medium-sized arteries and can lead to multi-organ involvement. Understanding the association between PAN and hepatitis B infection is crucial for the timely diagnosis and management of this potentially life-threatening condition.

choices.text: Decreased functional residual capacity
Decreased total lung capacity

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a 110-pack-year history of smoking presents to his primary care physician because of shortness of breath, dyspnea on exertion, and cough for three months’ duration. X-ray of the chest reveals flattened diaphragms bilaterally. The doctor orders pulmonary function tests to evaluate the patient. Which of the following pulmonary function test results would most likely be found in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Decreased FEV1:FVC

 

Explanation for each option:

 

Option A. Decreased FEV1:FVC: This is the correct answer. The ratio of forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1) to forced vital capacity (FVC) is used to assess airflow obstruction. In COPD, there is a reduction in FEV1 disproportionate to the reduction in FVC, leading to a decreased FEV1:FVC ratio, which is indicative of airflow obstruction.

 

Option B. Decreased functional residual capacity (FRC): In COPD, FRC is typically increased, not decreased, due to air trapping and the inability to fully exhale. This results in hyperinflation of the lungs.

 

Option C. Decreased total lung capacity (TLC): Total lung capacity may remain normal or even increase in COPD due to hyperinflation of the lungs and air trapping.

 

Option D. Increased FEV1:FVC: An increased FEV1:FVC ratio is not characteristic of COPD; instead, this finding might be seen in restrictive lung diseases where both FEV1 and FVC are reduced, but FEV1 is less affected, leading to a normal or increased ratio.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To understand the typical pulmonary function test findings in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), particularly the decreased FEV1:FVC ratio, which indicates airflow obstruction. Recognizing these findings is crucial for the diagnosis and management of COPD, facilitating appropriate treatment and monitoring of disease progression.

choices.text: Anterior tibial artery
Posterior tibial artery
Dorsalis pedis artery

questions.text: On examination on a patient of suspected Peripheral Arterial Disease, the doctor was seen to be performing the action shown in the given image. Which artery is he likely trying to palpate?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Posterior tibial artery

 

 

Option B. Posterior tibial: Palpated between medial malleolus and tendoachilles (image in question).

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Anterior tibial: palpated in lower leg between medial and lateral malleoli anteriorly.

 

Option C. Dorsalis pedis: Palpated in the foot lateral to tendon of extensor hallucis.

 

Option D. Popliteal: Palpated in the popliteal fossa (knee).

 

Educational objective: Understanding the different anatomical points for palpation of arterial pulsations in the limb is key. Posterior tibial pulsations are felt between medial malleolus and Achilles tendon.

 

Reference- A Manual on Clinical Surgery by S. Das, Page no. 85-87

choices.text: Galactosemia
Phenylketonuria
Cystic fibrosis
Neurofibromatosis

questions.text: A mother brings her child with the features of an Autosomal Recessive disease due to the deficiency of Phenyl alanine hydroxylase. On examination, the child is found to have Intellectual disability. All of the following Genetic disorders can lead to Intellectual disability except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cystic fibrosis

 

Cystic fibrosis is not associated with Intellectual disability.

 

Common Genetic Disorders associated with Intellectual disability are:

 

  • Galactosemia
  • Phenylketonuria
  • Homocystinuria
  • Argininemia
  • Lesch-nyhan disease
  • Maple syrup urine disease
  • Tyrosinemia
  • Tuberous sclerosis
  • Neurofibromatosis

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Identify and differentiate common genetic disorders associated with intellectual disability, recognizing that cystic fibrosis, primarily affecting the lungs and digestive system, is not typically associated with intellectual disability, unlike other metabolic conditions such as galactosemia and phenylketonuria.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition

choices.text: Lactate dehydrogenase
Carcinoembryonic antigen
Human placental lactogen
Alpha fetoprotein

questions.text: A 36-year-old man has noted increasing scrotal enlargement for the past 8 months. On physical examination, the left testis is enlarged and firm. Given below is the microscopic appearance of the excised mass, which grossly is reddish-brown and soft, with areas of hemorrhage on sectioning. He is referred for further therapy with retroperitoneal lymph node dissection and chemotherapy. Which of the following is the best laboratory test on his serum to aid in diagnosis and follow-up?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Alpha fetoprotein

 

Explanation for each option:

 

Option D. The patient's presentation of scrotal enlargement, firmness of the left testis, and the gross appearance of the excised mass with areas of hemorrhage are concerning for testicular cancer.

 

These primitive cells forming cords are typical for an embryonal carcinoma. This tumor often contains yolk sac elements and results in an elevated serum alpha fetoprotein (AFP).

 

Among the options, AFP is a tumor marker associated with non-seminomatous germ cell tumors (NSGCTs), a type of testicular cancer.

 

Elevated AFP levels in the serum can indicate the presence of NSGCT and are useful for diagnosis and monitoring response to treatment.

 

Option A. Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) is also a tumor marker for testicular cancer but is less specific than AFP. It can be elevated in various malignancies and non-malignant conditions.

 

Option B. Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) is not typically associated with testicular cancer; it is more commonly elevated in colorectal and other gastrointestinal cancers.

 

Option C. Human placental lactogen (HPL) is not a tumor marker for testicular cancer and is associated with pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Serum Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is the preferred laboratory test for diagnosing and monitoring non-seminomatous germ cell tumors (NSGCTs) in patients with testicular cancer.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to his pediatrician’s office by his parents, who reports that the child has been unusually thirsty for the past week. He also has increased urinary frequency and has wet the bed three times in the past two weeks. A random blood glucose level is 215 mg/dL. The pediatrician suspects that the child has type 1 diabetes mellitus caused by autoimmune destruction of insulin-producing pancreatic beta cells. Which of the following is the transporter for glucose to enter pancreatic beta cells?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) GLUT 2

 

Explanation for each option:

 

Option B. GLUT 2: GLUT 2 is the glucose transporter specifically found in pancreatic beta cells. It plays a crucial role in sensing blood glucose levels and allowing glucose to enter beta cells, where it can trigger insulin release in response to elevated blood glucose.

 

Option A. GLUT 1: GLUT 1 is a glucose transporter found in various cells throughout the body, including red blood cells and the blood-brain barrier. It is not the primary transporter for glucose entry into pancreatic beta cells.

 

Option C. GLUT 4: GLUT 4 is another glucose transporter, but it is primarily found in muscle and fat cells. GLUT 4 translocates to the cell membrane in response to insulin signaling and facilitates glucose uptake in these tissues. It is not the transporter responsible for glucose entry into pancreatic beta cells.

 

Option D. Simple diffusion: While glucose can passively diffuse into some cells, the entry of glucose into pancreatic beta cells is primarily facilitated by GLUT 2 transporters. Simple diffusion alone is not the main mechanism for glucose uptake in beta cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To understand the specific glucose transporter (GLUT 2) responsible for glucose entry into pancreatic beta cells. This knowledge is relevant in the context of type 1 diabetes mellitus, where autoimmune destruction of beta cells leads to impaired insulin production and glucose regulation.

choices.text: Between the glomerular basement membrane and visceral epithelium
Between the glomerular basement membrane and the podocytes
Between the glomerular basement membrane and the visceral epithelial cells
Between the endothelium and the mesangium

questions.text: Immune complex-mediated glomerular disease can be classified according to the site of complex formation. The site also partly dictates whether the disease would give rise to either a nephritic or a nephrotic clinical presentation. Where does the immune complex deposition form in membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Between the endothelium and the mesangium

 

Explanation for each option:

 

Option A. Between the glomerular basement membrane and visceral epithelium: This describes the subepithelial space, which is more characteristic of conditions like membranous nephropathy, where immune complexes deposit beneath the podocytes (visceral epithelial cells), not MPGN.

 

Option B. Between the glomerular basement membrane and the podocytes: This also refers to the subepithelial space and, as mentioned above, is not the typical site of immune complex deposition in MPGN.

 

Option C. Between the glomerular basement membrane and the visceral epithelial cells: This is another way of describing the subepithelial space, which, as noted, is not the primary site of deposition in MPGN.

 

Option D. Between the endothelium and the mesangium: This option accurately describes the subendothelial space, which, along with the mesangium, is where immune complex deposition typically occurs in MPGN. This leads to the characteristic structural changes seen in this disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To understand the pathophysiology of membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis, including the typical sites of immune complex deposition. Recognizing where immune complexes deposit in different types of glomerulonephritis can aid in understanding the disease process and its clinical manifestations, which is crucial for accurate diagnosis and management.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding tocolysis are correct?

 

  1. Atosiban is an oxytocin receptor antagonist 
  2. Indomethacin causes oligohydramnios which is irreversible and persists even with discontinuation of therapy
  3. β-Adrenergic receptor agonists can cause serious maternal morbidity including pulmonary edema, cardiac arrhythmias and myocardial ischemia
  4. Prolonged use of MgSO4 given to arrest preterm labor can cause bone thinning and fractures in fetuses exposed for more than 5-7 days.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 3, 4

 

Let’s Discuss all the Options:

 

  • Option A: Atosiban is an oxytocin receptor antagonist
  • Option B: Indomethacin causes oligohydramnios which is reversible with drug discontinuation. Indomethacin also causes Premature closure of the ductus arteriosus if given > 32 weeks
  • Option C: Beta adrenergic receptor agonists like ritodrine and Isoxsuprine are known to cause tachycardia, hypotension, pulmonary edema, myocardial ischemia and cardiac arrhythmias
  • Option D: Prolonged use of MgSO4 given to arrest preterm labor can cause bone thinning and fractures in fetuses exposed for more than 5-7 days due to low calcium levels in the fetus

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Indomethacin causes oligohydramnios which is reversible with drug discontinuation. Indomethacin also causes Premature closure of the ductus arteriosus if given > 32 weeks

 

Ref: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no. 806

questions.text: Identify the condition in which the following image is seen.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Buphthalmos

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows Haab's striae, which are horizontal breaks in Descemet's membrane caused by stretching, are a characteristic finding in buphthalmos.

 

Option A. Keratoglobus: Keratoglobus is a rare condition characterized by generalized corneal thinning and protrusion, resulting in a globular appearance of the cornea. It is not typically associated with Haab's striae.

 

Option B. Keratoconus: Keratoconus is a progressive condition characterized by corneal thinning and protrusion, leading to a conical shape of the cornea. Haab's striae are not typically observed in keratoconus.

 

Option C. Buphthalmos: Buphthalmos, also known as congenital or infantile glaucoma, is characterized by enlargement of the globe of the eye due to increased intraocular pressure during infancy or early childhood. Haab's striae, which are breaks in Descemet's membrane caused by stretching, are a characteristic finding in buphthalmos.

 

Option D. Senile cataract: Senile cataract refers to the opacification of the lens of the eye that occurs with aging. It does not typically present with Haab's striae.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognizing Haab's striae, which are characteristic breaks in Descemet's membrane caused by stretching, is important for diagnosing conditions such as buphthalmos (congenital glaucoma).

choices.text: Suprascapular artery passes above the suprascapular notch
Suprascapular nerve arises at Erb's point
If suprascapular nerve is injured at spinoglenoid notch, medial rotation of arm is affected
Articular branches to acromioclavicular joint arises from suprascapular nerve proximal to suprascapular notch

questions.text: A 65-year-old man, hard of hearing, while riding his motorbike met with a head-on collision with the truck on a national highway. He was thrown off the motorbike and fell down with an impact on his back a few metres away from the accident site. He was received in casualty. X-ray pictures taken showed multiple fractures of the left scapula. Which of the following statements is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) If suprascapular nerve is injured at spinoglenoid notch, medial rotation of arm is affected

 

Option C:

 

  • The suprascapular nerve primarily innervates the supraspinatus and infraspinatus muscles. These muscles are involved in the abduction and lateral rotation of the shoulder, respectively.
  • If the suprascapular nerve is injured at the spinoglenoid notch, it would predominantly affect the infraspinatus muscle, leading to difficulties in lateral rotation of the arm, not medial rotation.
  • This statement is incorrect. Injury to the suprascapular nerve at the spinoglenoid notch would impact lateral rotation, not medial rotation.
  • Suprascapular nerve supplies supraspinatus (initiates abduction upto 90 degree), then passes through spinoglenoid notch to supply infraspinatus (lateral rotator of arm).
  • Types of Scapular Fracture:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A.

 

  • The suprascapular artery typically passes over the suprascapular notch, while the suprascapular nerve passes under it through this notch.
  • Mnemonic:
    • N for Nerve, N for Navy (Navy is under water)
    • A for Artery, A for Air (Air is above)

 

 

Option B.

 

  • The Suprascapular Nerve originates from the upper trunk of the brachial plexus, which is formed by the union of the C5 and C6 nerve roots.
  • Erb's point refers to a site near the neck where nerves from the brachial plexus converge and are superficial enough to be impacted by trauma.

 

 

Option D.

 

  • The suprascapular nerve does give off articular branches to the shoulder joint, including the acromioclavicular joint. These branches typically arise before the nerve passes through the suprascapular notch.

 

Educational Objective:

 

If Suprascapular Nerve is Injured at Spinoglenoid Notch Medial Rotation of Arm is Affected: 

 

  • The suprascapular nerve primarily innervates the supraspinatus and infraspinatus muscles. These muscles are involved in the abduction and lateral rotation of the shoulder, respectively.
  • If the suprascapular nerve is injured at the spinoglenoid notch, it would predominantly affect the infraspinatus muscle, leading to difficulties in lateral rotation of the arm, not medial rotation.
  • This statement is incorrect. Injury to the suprascapular nerve at the spinoglenoid notch would impact lateral rotation, not medial rotation.

 

Ref: Gray’s Anatomy, 41st edition, page no. 831

choices.text: Her age
Estradiol level
Etiology of her infertility
Number of embryos transferred

questions.text: A 38-year-old patient with infertility secondary to tubal blockage just underwent in vitro fertilization (IVF). Her peak estradiol was 4500 pg/mL. Seventeen oocytes were retrieved, and two embryos were transferred. She conceived with a singleton gestation. She developed ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome. Which of the following was a predisposing factor in developing ovarian hyperstimulation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Estradiol level

 

Explanation

 

Risk factors for OHSS include

 

  • Young age (< 35 years)
  • Low BMI
  • PCOS
  • History of allergy/atopy
  • High serum estradiol
  • Previous h/o OHSS
  • Multiple follicles (PCOS)
  • High dose/ repeated doses of hCG
  • Pregnancy

 

Educational Objective

 

A high estradiol level increases the risk of developing ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS) in IVF cycles

 

Ref: Williams Gynecology, 3rd edition, Page no. 456

questions.text: Which of the following drugs reversibly binds to the site labelled as B in the given figure?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ticagrelor

 

Ticagrelor is a reversible antagonist of P2Y12 receptors of ADP whereas clopidogrel, ticlopidine and prasugrel are irreversible antagonist of ADP.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman came with a history of ischemic cardiomyopathy and left ventricular ejection fraction of 35%. She is NYHA class II in terms of symptoms. She is on valsartan, carvedilol, and spironolactone. Her blood pressure is 102/82 mmHg, and heart rate is 80 bpm. Which of the following additional medications will further reduce her mortality?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sacubitril

 

The patient described has heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF), characterized by a left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) of 35%, and is already on guideline-directed medical therapy (GDMT) with valsartan (angiotensin II receptor blocker, ARB), carvedilol (beta-blocker), and spironolactone (mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist, MRA). To further reduce mortality in such patients, the introduction of sacubitril/valsartan (combination of an angiotensin receptor-neprilysin inhibitor, ARNI) is highly recommended.

 

Sacubitril is part of the combination medication sacubitril/valsartan (Entresto), which has been shown in clinical trials (e.g., the PARADIGM-HF trial) to further reduce mortality and heart failure hospitalizations compared to valsartan or other ACE inhibitors/ARBs alone. Sacubitril inhibits neprilysin, leading to increased levels of beneficial peptides (e.g., natriuretic peptides) that counteract the harmful effects of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS). Switching the patient from valsartan to sacubitril/valsartan would improve outcomes in this context.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aliskiren: Aliskiren is a direct renin inhibitor. While it reduces blood pressure, it has not been proven to reduce mortality in heart failure patients. In fact, aliskiren use in patients with HFrEF and those already on RAAS inhibitors (like valsartan or spironolactone) can increase the risk of hyperkalemia and renal dysfunction without providing additional mortality benefits.

 

Option B. Digoxin: Digoxin is used in heart failure primarily for symptom control (i.e., reducing heart failure symptoms and controlling atrial fibrillation, if present). However, it does not reduce mortality. It is beneficial for improving symptoms and quality of life in patients with reduced ejection fraction but should not be considered a mortality-reducing therapy.

 

Option D. Lisinopril: Lisinopril is an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor (ACE inhibitor), which is part of the standard heart failure therapy and reduces mortality in HFrEF. However, the patient is already on valsartan, an ARB, which has a similar mechanism of action to lisinopril. It would not be appropriate to combine an ARB with an ACE inhibitor due to increased risks of hyperkalemia and renal dysfunction without added mortality benefit. Additionally, sacubitril/valsartan would be preferred over ACE inhibitors like lisinopril.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with HFrEF, switching to sacubitril/valsartan from an ACE inhibitor or ARB can further reduce mortality and heart failure hospitalizations. This combination improves neurohormonal modulation, helping to reduce disease progression. Other medications like digoxin and aliskiren have a limited role and do not confer mortality benefit, while ACE inhibitors like lisinopril are part of standard therapy but should not be combined with ARBs.

choices.text: The child is healthy; no further advice is required.
The child is moderately undernourished (MAM); the mother should be given advice.
The child is severely malnourished (SAM); the mother should be given advice.
The child is severely malnourished (SAM); refer to a Nutritional Rehabilitation Center (NRC).

questions.text: A Pediatrician is assessing a 13-month-old girl's growth chart during a routine health check-up. Referring to the WHO Child Growth Standards chart, the Pediatrician needs to decide the best management plan for this child. Based on the guidelines for the management of SAM at NRC as per NHM 2012, what is the most appropriate step to take next?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The child is moderately undernourished (MAM); the mother should be given advice.

 

Explanation:

 

In the given question, Growth chart wise child falls into category of mild-moderate malnutrition (between –2SD and –3SD, yellow zone)

 

Moderate Acute malnutrition - A child with 70-80% of median weight-for- height (Z score of <-3SD to <-2 SD), or a Mid Upper Arm Circumference of 115-125 cms and no oedema is classified as a case of Moderate Acute Malnutrition. In addition, the child should have appetite, be alert and clinically well. Children with moderate acute malnutrition can be managed in the Outpatients setting where there is a provision for supplementary feeding.

 

 

Other Definitions -

 

No Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) is MUAC > 115; or WFH > -3SD; and no bilateral pedal oedema: Nutrition counselling to mother/caregiver

 

Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) is WFH <–3SD/ and/or severe visible wasting and/or bilateral pedal oedema and/or MUAC < 115 mm

 

  • No medical complications: Refer to VHND or subcenter to be further assessment and counseling by ANM
  • Any one medical complication: Immediate referral to NRC
  • (Medical complications include poor appetite, visible severe wasting, edema of both feet, severe palmar pallor, any sick young infant (<2 months old), lethargy, drowsiness, unconsciousness, continually irritable and restless, any respiratory distress, signs suggesting severe dehydration in a child with diarrhoea)

 

Educational Objective

 

WHO CLASSIFICATION OF MALNUTRITION
